Overall, the aim was for a reduction of 70% in badger populations over the successive culls.<ref name="ITV West Country">{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/westcountry/topic/badger-cull/|publisher=ITV|title=Badger cull|date=9 September 2014|accessdate=11 September 2014}}</ref> This was to be achieved with an emphasis on trapping badgers in cages and shooting them at dawn, rather than "free shooting".<ref name="The Guardian Tranquility">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/sep/11/badger-cull-vigil-police-campaigners|publisher=The Guardian|author=Barkham, P.|date=11 September 2014|title=Badger cull: tranquil nights, uneasy vigil and a change of police tactics|accessdate=11 September 2014}}</ref>
====Protests==== As in the 2013/14 cull, hundreds of protesters entered the culling areas to disrupt the badgers causing them to remain down their setts and avoiding being trapped and/or shot, or to look for injured badgers. On 9 September 2014, two saboteurs in Gloucestershire found a badger trapped in a cage with cullers nearby. The police were called and the saboteurs pointed out that under government guidelines, trapped badgers should be released if there was a risk of interference from a third party. The sabateur organisation, "Stop the Cull" said police "did the right thing" and freed the badger. Gloucestershire police confirmed the standoff, which it said was resolved peacefully – adding the decision to release the badger was made by a contractor working for the cull operator.<ref name="Guardian cull protesters">{{cite news|author=Morris, S.|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/sep/09/bagder-cull-protesters-save-animal-second-cull|title=Badger cull protesters save trapped animal as second phase starts|date=9 September 2014|accessdate=13 September 2014}}</ref>
Dr [[Brian May]], guitarist with the rock band [[Queen (band)|Queen]] is a critic of badger culling in the UK. He has called for the 2014/15 cull to be cancelled. "It's almost beyond belief that the government is blundering ahead with a second year of inept and barbaric badger killing," he said.<ref name="Guardian cull protesters" />
Organisations involved in protesting the cull include:
* Team Badger: representing 25 different organisations * Gloucestershire Against the Badger Shooting (Gabs){{citation needed|date=May 2016}}
====Policing==== In the 2013/2014 cull, police from forces including Sussex, Warwickshire, Cornwall and the Metropolitan Police were brought in to help with policing, however, the police have said that in the 2014/2015 cull, there will be a focus on more community policing with local officers on patrol. "It will be very focussed on Gloucestershire officers dealing will local issues."<ref name="BBC fewer police">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-gloucestershire-29066496|title='Fewer police' for this years badger cull in Gloucestershire|publisher=BBC|accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==Further reading== * [[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]]: ''[http://www.defra.gov.uk/publications/2011/12/14/pb13691-bovine-tb-badger-control/ The Government's Policy on Bovine TB and badger control in England]'', published 14 December 2011, retrieved 16 July 2012. * [[Food and Environment Research Agency]]: ''[http://www.fera.defra.gov.uk/wildlife/ecologyManagement/documents/vaccinationFAQs.pdf Vaccination Q&A]'', retrieved 17 July 2012.
==External links== * [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1992/51/pdfs/ukpga_19920051_en.pdf The Protection of Badgers Act 1992] * [http://www.wildlifeonline.me.uk/badgers_tb.html WildlifeOnline{{snd}} Badgers and Bovine TB]

{{flag|Republic of China (1912–1949)|name=Republic of China}} |serviceyears = 1907–1949 |rank = [[General]] |commands = Minister Of National Defense, Central China Pacification Director |unit = [[New Guangxi Clique]] |battles = [[Northern Expedition]]

[[Campaign to Defend Siping]] |awards = [[Order of Blue Sky and White Sun]] |laterwork = Director General of the [[Chinese Muslim Association]] |portrayedby = }} {{Chinese name|[[Bai (surname)|Bai]]}} '''Bai Chongxi''' (18 March 1893 – 1 December 1966; {{zh|c=白崇禧 |p=Bái Chóngxǐ |w='''''Pai Ch'ung-hsi'''''}}; {{IPA-cmn|pɑ́ɪ̯ t͡ʂʰʊ́ŋɕǐ|IPA}}, [[Xiao'erjing]]: {{lang|zh-Arab|ﺑَﻰْ ﭼْﻮ ثِ }}) was a Chinese general in the [[National Revolutionary Army]] of the [[Republic of China (1912–1949)|Republic of China]] (ROC) and a prominent Chinese Nationalist leader.[http://library.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=12Q8G1293B417.21992&profile=th&uindex=SW&term=Bai,%20Chongxi,%201893-1966.&aspect=basic_search&menu=search&source=10.10.10.111@!horizon Listed General]{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, City of Sydney Library, accessed July 2009 He was of [[Hui people|Hui]] ethnicity and of the Muslim faith. From the mid-1920s to 1949, Bai and his close ally [[Li Zongren]] ruled [[Guangxi]] province as regional warlords with their own troops and considerable political autonomy. His relationship with [[Chiang Kai-shek]] was at various times antagonistic and cooperative. He and Li Zongren supported the anti-Chiang warlord alliance in the [[Central Plains War]] in 1930, then supported Chiang in the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] and the [[Chinese Civil War]]. Bai was the first defense minister of the Republic of China from 1946-48. After losing to the Communists in 1949, he fled to Taiwan, where he died in 1966. ==Warlord era== Bai was born in [[Guilin]], Guangxi, and given the [[courtesy name]] '''Jiansheng''' ({{lang|zh|健生}}). He was a descendant of a Persian merchant of the name Baiderluden, whose descendants adopted the Chinese surname Bai. His Muslim name was [[Omar (name)|Omar]] Bai Chongxi.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?ct=result&id=iTogAAAAMAAJ&dq=The+Chief+of+the+General+Staff+of+All+Chinese+Land-Sea-and-Air+muslim&q=The+Chief+of+the+General+Staff+of+All+Chinese+Land-Sea-and-Air+was+general+omar+pei|title=Islam in China|author=M. Rafiq Khan|year=1963|publisher=National Academy|location=Delhi|isbn=|page=17}} He was the second of three sons. His family was said to have come from [[Sichuan]]. At the age of 14 he attended the Guangxi Military Cadre Training School in Guilin, a modern-style school run by [[Cai E]] to modernize Guangxi's military. Bai and classmates [[Huang Shaohong]] and [[Li Zongren]] would become the three leading figures of Guangxi's military. For a time Bai withdrew from the military school at the request of his family and studied at the civilian Guangxi Schools of Law and Political Science. With the outbreak of the [[Xinhai Revolution]] in 1911, under the leadership of [[Huang Shaoxiong]], Bai joined a Students Dare to Die corps. After entering the Nanjing Enlistment Corps he transferred from the Corps to the Second Military Preparatory School at [[Wuchang District|Wuchang]]. He graduated from the school in 1914, then underwent pre-cadet training for six months before attending the third class of [[Baoding Military Academy]] in June 1915. He became a 1st Guangxi Division probationary officer upon returning to Guangxi.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r3AJFusMHJwC&pg=PA51 |title=Biographical dictionary of Republican China, Volume 3|author1=Howard L. Boorman |author2=Richard C. Howard |author3=Joseph K.H. Cheng |year=1979|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York City|isbn=0-231-08957-0|pages=51–56}} Bai rose to fame during the [[warlord era]] by allying with [[Huang Shaohong]] (a fellow deputy commander of the Model Battalion of the Guangxi First Division) and [[Li Tsung-jen]] as supporters of [[Kuomintang]] leader [[Sun Yat-sen]]. This alliance, called the [[New Guangxi Clique]], proceeded to move against Guangxi warlord [[Lu Rongting]] in 1924. The coalition's efforts brought Guangxi Province under ROC jurisdiction, and Pai and Li represented a new generation of Guangxi leaders. The Nationalist chief of staff (acting) was Bai.{{cite book|title=Current Biography Yearbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8pkYAAAAIAAJ&q=pai+tsung+hsi+Emily+Hahn&dq=pai+tsung+hsi+Emily+Hahn&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwivy5uU1ZHPAhWKMx4KHaMeBYMQ6AEINDAE|year=1942|publisher=H. W. Wilson Company|page=516}} The 13th Army had him as the commander.{{cite book|author1=Maxine Block|author2=E. Mary Trow|title=Current Biography: Who's News and Why, 1942|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bLSDTRdhgKMC&q=pai+tsung+hsi+Emily+Hahn&dq=pai+tsung+hsi+Emily+Hahn&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwivy5uU1ZHPAhWKMx4KHaMeBYMQ6AEILjAD|date=1 January 1942|publisher=Hw Wilson Company|isbn=978-0-8242-0479-2|page=516}} The Nationalist Northern Punitive Expedition was participated in by Bai.{{cite book|author1=Maxine Block|author2=E. Mary Trow|title=Current Biography: Who's News and Why, 1942|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bLSDTRdhgKMC&q=pai+tsung+hsi+Emily+Hahn&dq=pai+tsung+hsi+Emily+Hahn&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwivy5uU1ZHPAhWKMx4KHaMeBYMQ6AEILjAD|date=1 January 1942|publisher=Hw Wilson Company|isbn=978-0-8242-0479-2|page=516}} During the [[Northern Expedition (1926–1927)|Northern Expedition]] (1926–28) Bai was the Chief of Staff of the [[National Revolutionary Army]] and credited with many victories over the northern warlords, often using speed, maneuver and surprise to defeat larger enemy forces. He led the Eastern Route Army that conquered [[Hangzhou]] and [[Shanghai]] in 1927. As garrison commander of Shanghai, he also took part in the purge of Communist elements of the National Revolutionary Army on April 4, 1927, and of the [[labor union]]s in Shanghai. Bai also commanded the forward units that first entered Beijing and was credited with being the senior commander on site to complete the Northern Expedition. For many of his battlefield exploits during the Northern expedition, he was given the laudatory nickname '''Xiao Zhuge''', literally "little [[Zhuge Liang]]," of the [[Three Kingdoms]] fame. Bai was the commander of Kuomintang forces in the [[Shanghai massacre of 1927]], where he directed the KMT purge of Communists in the party. In 1928, during the [[Northern Expedition]], Bai led [[Kuomintang]] forces in the defeat and destruction of [[Fengtian Clique]] Gen. [[Zhang Zongchang]], capturing 20,000 of his 50,000 troops and almost capturing Zhang himself, who escaped to Manchuria.{{cite news |title=CHINA: Potent Hero|newspaper=TIME|date=Sep 24, 1928|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,928072,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} [[File:NRA Generals Northern Expedition.jpg|thumb|left|220px|Chinese generals pay tribute to the [[Sun Yat-sen]] Mausoleum in Beijing in 1928 after the success of the Northern Expedition. From right to left, are Gen. [[Cheng Jin]], Gen. [[Zhang Zuobao]], Gen. [[Chen Diaoyuan]], Gen. [[Chiang Kai-shek]], Gen. [[Woo Tsin-hang]], Gen. [[Yan Xishan]], Gen. [[Ma Fuxiang]], Gen. [[Ma Sida]] and Gen. Bai Chongxi.]] Bai personally had around 2,000 Muslims under his control during his stay in [[Beijing]] in 1928 after the [[Northern Expedition]] was completed; it was reported by TIME magazine that they "swaggered riotously" in the aftermath{{cite news |title=CHINA: Prattling|newspaper=TIME|date=Sep 3, 1928|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,928007,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} In June 1928 in [[Beijing]], Bai Chongxi announced that the forces of the Kuomintang would seize control of Manchuria and the enemies of the Kuomintang would "scatter like dead leaves before the rising wind". Bai was out of money and bankrupt in December 1928. He planned to lead 60,000 troops from east China to [[Xinjiang]] province and construct a railroad as a barrier against Russian encroachment in Xinjiang. His plan was perceived by some to be against [[Feng Yuxiang]].{{cite news |title=BANKRUPT PEI STUNS CHINA BY AMBITIONS; Hopes to March 60,000 Unpaid Troops 1,000 Miles and Colonize Sinkiang.RAILWAY LINE PLANNED Scheme Is to Erect Bulwark Against Russia--Project Is Viewed as Blow at Feng.|newspaper=THE NEW YORK TIMES|date=12 December 1928|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1928/12/12/archives/bankrupt-pei-stuns-china-by-ambitions-hopes-to-march-60000-unpaid.html|accessdate=December 12, 2010}} The Military Council refused to authorize him leaving Peiping to go to Hankow.{{cite book|title=The China Monthly Review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5pY3GwYflX8C&q=General+Pai+Tsung-hsi%27s+departure+for+Hankow+from+Peiping+is+countermanded+by+order+of+the+Militarv+Council,+which+states+that&dq=General+Pai+Tsung-hsi%27s+departure+for+Hankow+from+Peiping+is+countermanded+by+order+of+the+Militarv+Council,+which+states+that&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjurKv52JHPAhUELB4KHYmSAeMQ6AEIIDAA|year=1928|publisher=Millard Publishing Company, Incorporated|page=31}} At the end of the [[Northern Expedition]], [[Chiang Kai-shek]] began to agitate to get rid of the Guangxi forces. At one time in 1929 Bai had to escape to [[Vietnam]] to avoid harm. Hubei and Guangxi were subjected to the Hankou subcouncil of Li Zongren and Bai Chongxi.{{cite book|author=Emily Hahn|title=Chiang Kai-Shek: An Unauthorized Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8VPVCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT88&dq=pai+tsung+hsi+Emily+Hahn&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwivy5uU1ZHPAhWKMx4KHaMeBYMQ6AEIIjAB#v=onepage&q=pai%20tsung%20hsi%20Emily%20Hahn&f=false|date=13 October 2015|publisher=Open Road Media|isbn=978-1-5040-1627-8|pages=}} Li and Bai's Hankou and Canton self-ruling governments were terminated by Chiang.{{cite book|author=Emily Hahn|title=China Only Yesterday: 1850–1950: A Century of Change|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FlTVCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT292&dq=pai+tsung+hsi+Emily+Hahn&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwivy5uU1ZHPAhWKMx4KHaMeBYMQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=pai%20tsung%20hsi%20Emily%20Hahn&f=false|date=28 July 2015|publisher=Open Road Media|isbn=978-1-5040-1628-5|pages=362–}} Hankou was captured by Chiang during the dispute between the Guangxi faction and Nanjing.{{cite book|author=Emily Hahn|title=The Soong Sisters|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7tcqAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT275&dq=pai+tsung+hsi+Emily+Hahn&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwivy5uU1ZHPAhWKMx4KHaMeBYMQ6AEIKDAC#v=onepage&q=pai%20tsung%20hsi%20Emily%20Hahn&f=false|date=1 April 2014|publisher=Open Road Media|isbn=978-1-4976-1953-1|pages=}}{{cite book|author=Emily Hahn|title=The Song Sisters|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1axcvAWFsz0C&q=emily+hahn+kwang+si&dq=emily+hahn+kwang+si&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjU-JHxj5LPAhUFWh4KHX9cDPkQ6AEIHDAA|year=1943|page=152}} From 1930-36 Bai was instrumental in the [[Reconstruction of Guangxi]], which became a "model" province with a [[progressivism|progressive]] administration. Guangxi supplied over 900,000 soldiers to the war effort against Japan. During the [[Chinese Civil War]] Bai fought against the Communists. In the [[Long March]] he allowed the Communists to slip through [[Guangxi]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HlttAAAAMAAJ&q=Pai+Chung-hsi+has+at+times+attacked+the+Reds,+though+he+winked+at+their+passage+through+a+part+of+his+Kwangsi+domain+during+the+Long+March,+on+severe+conditions+.+The+story+is+told+that+he+once+saved+the+life+of+Chou+En-lai&dq=Pai+Chung-hsi+has+at+times+attacked+the+Reds,+though+he+winked+at+their+passage+through+a+part+of+his+Kwangsi+domain+during+the+Long+March,+on+severe+conditions+.+The+story+is+told+that+he+once+saved+the+life+of+Chou+En-lai|title=Inside Asia|author=John Gunther|year=1942|publisher=Harper & Brothers|location=|isbn=|page=281|accessdate=2011-06-04}} Governing his province aptly and capably were two of the things Bai was renowned for in China.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=knfZAAAAMAAJ&q=gunther+inside+asia+pai+reputation&dq=gunther+inside+asia+pai+reputation|title=Historical magazine of the Protestant Episcopal Church, Volume 50|author=Church Historical Society (U.S.)|editors=Walter Herbert Stowe, Lawrence L. Brown|year=1981|publisher=Church Historical Society.|location=|isbn=|page=183|accessdate=2011-06-04}} Prominent Muslims like Gen. [[Ma Liang)]], [[Ma Fuxiang]] and Bai Chongxi met in 1931 in Nanjing to discuss intercommunal tolerance between Hui and Han.{{cite book|title=Contemporary Japan: A Review of Japanese Affairs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9IsTAAAAIAAJ&dq=General+Pai+Chung-hsi+wields+a+great+influence+over+military+circles+in+northwestern+China+as+deputy+leader+of+the+...+He+is+also+popular+among+the+Mohammedans+in+China+as+chairman+of+the+Muslim+League%2C+which+was+organized+after+the&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=pai+chung|year=1942|publisher=Foreign affairs association of Japan.|page=1626}} ==Second Sino-Japanese War== [[File:Liangyou 137 cover - Bai Chongxi.jpg|thumb|upright|In May 1938, Bai Chongxi appeared on the cover of ''[[The Young Companion]]'']] The 4th Army Groups chief of staff was Bai Chongxi.{{cite book|title=The China Monthly Review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_34TAAAAIAAJ&q=Pai+Tsung-hsi,+chief+of+staff+of+the+Foutrh+Army+Grou+was+%22really+admirable,%22+Col.+Nemoto+said&dq=Pai+Tsung-hsi,+chief+of+staff+of+the+Foutrh+Army+Grou+was+%22really+admirable,%22+Col.+Nemoto+said&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiW8d6xpJLPAhWE1B4KHcNdBXYQ6AEIHjAA|year=1935|publisher=J.W. Powell|page=214}}{{cite book|title=China Monthly Review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2UooAAAAMAAJ&q=Pai+Tsung-hsi,+chief+of+staff+of+the+Foutrh+Army+Group,+was+%22really+admirable,%22+Col.+Nemoto+said&dq=Pai+Tsung-hsi,+chief+of+staff+of+the+Foutrh+Army+Group,+was+%22really+admirable,%22+Col.+Nemoto+said&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiT4py1pJLPAhXBGR4KHcpKDVEQ6AEIHjAA|year=1935|publisher=Millard Publishing Company, Incorporated|page=214}} An anti-Japanese war was called for by Bai Chongxi, [[Li Zongren]] and [[Chen Jitang]] in 1936.{{cite book|author=Emily Hahn|title=Chiang Kai-shek: An Unauthorized Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HFWlaMnvu6MC&q=pai+chung+Emily+Hahn&dq=pai+chung+Emily+Hahn&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwis-ZD51JHPAhXGmh4KHQRHAfUQ6AEIHDAA|year=1955|publisher=Doubleday|page=192}} The mance posed by Japan was seen by Bai chongxi and Li Zongren.{{cite book|author=Emily Hahn|title=Chiang Kai-shek: An Unauthorized Biography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HFWlaMnvu6MC&dq=pai+chung+Emily+Hahn&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=pai+chung+japanese|year=1955|publisher=Doubleday|page=228}} Formal hostilities broke out on 7 July 1937 between China and Japan with the [[Marco Polo Bridge Incident]] outside Beijing. On 4 August 1937 Bai rejoined the Central Government at the invitation of Chiang Kai-shek. During the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] (1937–45), he was the Deputy Chief of the General Staff responsible for operations and training. He was the key strategist who convinced Chiang to adopt a "Total War" strategy in which China would trade space for time, adopt guerrilla tactics behind enemy lines and disrupt enemy supply lines at every opportunity. When the better armed and trained Japanese troops advanced, the Chinese would adopt a [[scorched earth]] campaign in the enemy's path to deny them local supply. Bai was also involved in many key campaigns including the first major victory at the [[Battle of Tai'erzhuang]] in [[Shandong Province]] in the spring of 1938 when he teamed up with Gen. [[Li Zongren]] to defeat a superior enemy. China managed to check and delay the Japanese advance for several months. Subsequently, Bai was appointed Commander of the Field Executive Office of the Military Council in Guilin, with responsibility for the 3rd, 4th, 7th and 9th War Zones. In that capacity he oversaw the successful defense of [[Changsha]], capital of Hunan Province. Between 1939-42 the Japanese attacked Changsha three times and were repelled each time. Bai also directed the [[Battle of South Guangxi]] and [[Battle of Kunlun Pass]] to retake South Guangxi. The 64th Army and 46th Army were requested to be outfitted by Bai via Gen. Lindsey.{{cite book|title=China-Burma-India Theater: Stilwell's Command Problems|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8eMv1piDCPkC&pg=PA401&dq=gas+pai+chung+hsi+japanese&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFncyD2ZHPAhXELB4KHXvsCzcQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=gas%20pai%20chung%20hsi%20japanese&f=false|year=1956|publisher=Government Printing Office|isbn=978-0-16-088233-3|pages=401–}} Bai's Guangxi soldiers were praised as a "crack"(as in elite) army during the war against Japan, and he was known to be an able general who could lead the Chinese resistance should Chiang Kai-shek be assassinated.{{cite news |title=Background For War: ASIA - Chiang's War|newspaper=TIME|date=Jun 26, 1939|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,931319-4,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} The majority of Chinese presumed that Chiang Kai-shek, as leader of China, tapped Bai to inherit his position.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HlttAAAAMAAJ&q=It+is+generally+believed+that+he+has+been+chosen+by+the+Generalissimo+to+be+his+political+successor.+Most+people+in+China+would+say+that+he+was+No.+2+to+Chiang+in+a+political+sense,+as+Pai+is+No&dq=It+is+generally+believed+that+he+has+been+chosen+by+the+Generalissimo+to+be+his+political+successor.+Most+people+in+China+would+say+that+he+was+No.+2+to+Chiang+in+a+political+sense,+as+Pai+is+No|title=Inside Asia|author=John Gunther|year=1942|publisher=Harper & Brothers|location=|isbn=|page=281|accessdate=2011-06-04}} Bai Chongxi led the competent Guangxi Army against the Japanese.{{cite book|title=Far Eastern Affairs and The American Spokesman|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NjULAQAAMAAJ&q=Its+army+is+large,+efficient,+and+politically+conscious,+its+commander,+General+Pai+Chung-hsi,+an+able+and+intelligent+soldier.&dq=Its+army+is+large,+efficient,+and+politically+conscious,+its+commander,+General+Pai+Chung-hsi,+an+able+and+intelligent+soldier.&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiz8KzPsJLPAhWKGx4KHWWwDl8Q6AEIITAB|year=1939|page=41}}{{cite book|author=Isoshi Asahi|title=The Economic Strength of Japan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6QpBAAAAIAAJ&q=Its+army+is+large,+efficient,+and+politically+conscious,+its+commander,+General+Pai+Chung-hsi,+an+able+and+intelligent+soldier.&dq=Its+army+is+large,+efficient,+and+politically+conscious,+its+commander,+General+Pai+Chung-hsi,+an+able+and+intelligent+soldier.&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiz8KzPsJLPAhWKGx4KHWWwDl8Q6AEIHDAA|year=1939|publisher=Tokyo|page=2}} In refusing to obey commands from Chiang if he assumed them to be wrong and flawed, Bai Chongxi was alone among fellow military men.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?ct=result&id=bLSDTRdhgKMC&dq=On+the+other+hand%2C+Pai+Tsung-hsi+is+said+to+be+the+only+man+who+dares+to+countermand+Chiang%27s+military+orders+in+the&q=countermand|title=Current Biography: Who's News and Why, 1942|author1=Maxine Block |author2=E. Mary Trow |year=1942|publisher=Hw Wilson Co|edition=reprint|location=|isbn=0-8242-0479-4|page=518|accessdate=2010-06-28}} [[Jihad]] was declared obligatory and a religious duty for all Chinese Muslims against Japan after 1937 during the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MJzB6wrz6Q4C&dq=ma+fuxiang+defence&q=jihad+japan#v=snippet&q=jihad%20japan%20sacred%20muslims%20china&f=false|title=Intellectuals in the modern Islamic world: transmission, transformation, communication|author1=Stéphane A. Dudoignon |author2=Hisao Komatsu |author3=Yasushi Kosugi |year=2006|publisher=Taylor & Francis|location=|pages=135, 336|isbn=978-0-415-36835-3|accessdate=2010-06-28}} Bai also sheltered the Muslim Yuehua publication in [[Guilin]], which printed quotes from the [[Quran]] and [[Hadith]] justifying the need for [[Chiang Kai-shek]] as leader of China.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MJzB6wrz6Q4C&pg=PA135&dq=china+jihad+japan+xue+chengda#v=snippet&q=jiang%20hadith%20jieshi%20leader&f=false|title=Intellectuals in the modern Islamic world: transmission, transformation, communication|author1=Stéphane A. Dudoignon |author2=Hisao Komatsu |author3=Yasushi Kosugi |year=2006|publisher=Taylor & Francis|location=|page=134|isbn=978-0-415-36835-3|accessdate=2010-06-28}} Bai promoted Chinese nationalism and uniting Hui to the Han during the war against Japan.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MJzB6wrz6Q4C&dq=ma+fuxiang+defence&q=bai+chongxi#v=snippet&q=bai%20chongxi%20uniting&f=false|title=Intellectuals in the modern Islamic world: transmission, transformation, communication|author1=Stéphane A. Dudoignon |author2=Hisao Komatsu |author3=Yasushi Kosugi |year=2006 |publisher= Taylor & Francis |page=336 of 352 |isbn= 978-0-415-36835-3 |accessdate=2010-06-28}} During the war, Bai traveled throughout the Muslim northwestern provinces of China controlled by the [[Ma Clique]] and met with Ma Clique generals to defeat Japanese propaganda.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HlttAAAAMAAJ&q=During+the+present+war+he+took+a+long+trip+through+Kansu+and+the+Northwest,+sounding+out+Moslem+opinion+and+counteracting+Japanese+propaganda,+seeking+to+keep+the+Mohammedans+safe+for+China+in+the+critical+region+where+they+control+the&dq=During+the+present+war+he+took+a+long+trip+through+Kansu+and+the+Northwest,+sounding+out+Moslem+opinion+and+counteracting+Japanese+propaganda,+seeking+to+keep+the+Mohammedans+safe+for+China+in+the+critical+region+where+they+control+the|title=Inside Asia|author=John Gunther|year=1942|publisher=Harper & Brothers|location=|isbn=|page=280|accessdate=2010-06-28}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=riDT0BxwpMAC&pg=PA281&dq=pai+chung-hsi+name#v=snippet&q=pai%20chung-hsi%20kansu%20moslem&f=false|title=Inside Asia - 1942 War Edition|author=John Gunther|year=2007|publisher=READ BOOKS|location=|isbn=1-4067-1532-8|page=280|accessdate=2010-06-28}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bLSDTRdhgKMC&q=He+has+succeeded+in+keeping+loyal+to+China+the+Mohammedan+troops+in+those+provinces,+which+occupy+a+strategic+position+athwart+the+northwest+line+of+communications+that+extends+to+the+USSR+Li+Tsung-jen+is+described+by+John+Gunther+as&dq=He+has+succeeded+in+keeping+loyal+to+China+the+Mohammedan+troops+in+those+provinces,+which+occupy+a+strategic+position+athwart+the+northwest+line+of+communications+that+extends+to+the+USSR+Li+Tsung-jen+is+described+by+John+Gunther+as|title=Current Biography: Who's News and Why, 1942|author1=Maxine Block |author2=E. Mary Trow |year=1942|publisher=Hw Wilson Co|edition=reprint|location=|isbn=0-8242-0479-4|page=518|accessdate=2010-06-28}} The Hui Muslim [[Xidaotang]] sect pledged allegiance to the Kuomintang after their rise to power and Bai Chongxi acquainted [[Chiang Kai-shek]] with the Xidaotang jiaozhu Ma Mingren in 1941 in [[Chongqing]].{{cite book|author=Jonathan Neaman Lipman|title=Familiar strangers: a history of Muslims in Northwest China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y8Nzux7z6KAC&pg=PA197#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=1 July 1998|publisher=University of Washington Press|isbn=978-0-295-80055-4|pages=197–}} Bai Chongxi headed the Chinese Islamic National Salvation Federation.{{cite book|title=China Magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tdg4AQAAIAAJ&q=gas+pai+chung+hsi+japanese&dq=gas+pai+chung+hsi+japanese&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFncyD2ZHPAhXELB4KHXvsCzcQ6AEIMjAF|year=1942|page=68}}{{cite book|title=China at War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T4dKAAAAMAAJ&q=gas+pai+chung+hsi+japanese&dq=gas+pai+chung+hsi+japanese&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiFncyD2ZHPAhXELB4KHXvsCzcQ6AEINjAG|year=1942|publisher=China Information Publishing Company|page=68}} ==Chinese Civil War== [[File:國防部長白崇禧報告.jpg|thumb|Bai Chongxi as the [[Ministry of National Defense of the Republic of China|1st Minister of National Defense]] of the Republic of China after the [[Constitution of the Republic of China|1947 Constitution]].]] Following the [[surrender of Japan]] in 1945, the [[Chinese Civil War]] resumed in full-fledged fighting. In the spring of 1946 the [[Communist Party of China|Chinese Communists]] were active in [[Manchuria]]. A crack [[People's Liberation Army]] unit of 100,000 strong under the Communist Gen. [[Lin Biao]] occupied a key railroad junction at [[Siping City|Siping]]. Kuomintang forces could not dislodge them after several attempts; Chiang Kai-shek then sent Bai to oversee the operation. After some redeployment, Nationalist forces were able to decisively defeat Lin's forces after a two-day pitched battle. This was to be the first major victory for the Kuomintang in the 1946-49 stage of the civil war before the fall of mainland China to the Chinese Communists. In June 1946 Bai was appointed Minister of National Defense.{{cite web|url=http://www.generals.dk/general/Bai_Chongxi/_/China.html|title=Biography of General 1st Rank Bai Chongxi - (白崇禧) - (Pai Chung-hsi) (1893 – 1966), China|publisher=|accessdate=24 May 2016}} It turned to be a post without power, as Chiang began to bypass Bai on major decisions regarding the Chinese Civil War. Chiang would hold daily briefings in his residence without inviting Bai and began to direct front-line troops personally down to the division level, bypassing the chain of command. The Civil War went poorly for the Kuomintang as Chiang's strategy of holding onto provincial capitals and leaving the countryside to the Communists very quickly caused the downfall of his forces, which had a 4:1 numerical superiority at the beginning of the conflict. During the [[Ili Rebellion]] Bai was considered by the government for the post of Governor of [[Xinjiang]]. The position later was given to [[Masud Sabri]], a pro-Kuomintang Uyghur leader. In April 1948 the first National Assembly in China convened in Nanjing, with thousands of delegates from all over China representing different provinces and ethnic groups. Bai Chongxi, acting as Minister of National Defense, debriefed the Assembly on the military situation, completely ignoring Northern China and Manchuria in his report. Delegates from Manchuria in the assembly responded by yelling out and calling for the death of those responsible for the loss of Manchuria.{{cite news |title=CHINA: Sorrow for Old Chiang|newspaper=TIME|date=Apr 26, 1948|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,798460,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} In November 1948 Bai, in command of forces in Hankow, met with Generals [[Fu Zuoyi]], [[Chang Chih-chung]] and Chiang Kai-shek in Nanjing about defending [[Suzhou]], the gateway to the Yangzi River valley.{{cite news |title=CHINA: If the Heart Is Pierced|newspaper=TIME|date=Nov 15, 1948|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,853413,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} Bai told the Central Political Council of the Kuomintang that negotiating with the Communists would only make them more powerful.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n50TAAAAIAAJ&q=In+his+report+to+the+Central+Political+Council+of+the+Kuomintang,+General+Pai+Chung-hsi,+Minister+of+National+Defence,+said+General+George+C.+Marshall's+peace+negotiations+were+the+main+cause+of+the+Chinese+Communist+power+and+the&dq=In+his+report+to+the+Central+Political+Council+of+the+Kuomintang,+General+Pai+Chung-hsi,+Minister+of+National+Defence,+said+General+George+C.+Marshall's+peace+negotiations+were+the+main+cause+of+the+Chinese+Communist+power+and+the|title=The China monthly review, Volume 109|year=1948|publisher=J.W. Powell|location=|isbn=|page=56|accessdate=2010-06-28}} Governor of Hunan [[Cheng Qian]], and Bai reached a consensus that they should impede the advance of the Communists by negotiating with them.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PdKGAAAAIAAJ&q=That+December,+Pai+and+the+Governor+of+Hunan,+General+Ch'eng+Ch'ien,+went+into+rather+frequent+secret+huddles.+The+two+men+agreed+that+only+by+negotiating+with+the+Communists+could+they+delay+the+Red+offensive.+Pai+went+into+action+with&dq=That+December,+Pai+and+the+Governor+of+Hunan,+General+Ch'eng+Ch'ien,+went+into+rather+frequent+secret+huddles.+The+two+men+agreed+that+only+by+negotiating+with+the+Communists+could+they+delay+the+Red+offensive.+Pai+went+into+action+with|title=The man who lost China: the first full biography of Chiang Kai-shek|author1=Brian Crozier |author2=Eric Chou |year=1976|publisher=Scribner|location=|isbn=0-684-14686-X|page=322|accessdate=2010-06-28}} In January 1949, with the Communists close to victory, almost everyone in the Nationalist media, political and military command began to demand peace as a slogan and turn against Chiang. Bai Chongxi decided to follow suit with the mainstream current and defied Chiang Kai-shek's orders, refusing to battle Communists near the Huai River and demanding that his soldiers, which were "lent", be sent back to him so he could secure his hold n the province of Guangxi and ignore the central government in Nanjing. Bai was the commander of four armies in Central China in the Hankow region. He demanded that the government negotiate with the Communists like the others.{{cite news |title=CHINA: When Headlines Cry Peace|newspaper=TIME|date=Jan 17, 1949|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,780095,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} Bai was in charge of the defense of the capital, Nanjing. He sent a telegram requesting that Chiang Kai-shek step down as President, amid a storm of requests by other Kuomintang military and political figures for Chiang to step down and allow a peace deal with the Communists.{{cite news |title=Foreign News: Sugar-Coated Poison|newspaper=TIME|date=Jan 10, 1949|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,804969,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} When Communist Gen. [[Lin Biao]] mounted an attack on Bai Chongxi's forces in Hankow, they retreated quickly, leaving the "rice bowl" of China open for the Communists.{{cite news |title=CHINA: The Weary Wait|newspaper=TIME|date=May 23, 1949|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,794751,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} Bai retreated to Headquarters at [[Hengyang]] via a railroad from [[Hankow]] to [[Canton (Guangzhou)|Canton]]. The railroad then provided access to [[Guilin]] where his home was.{{cite news |title=CHINA: Defend the Graveyard|newspaper=TIME|date=May 30, 1949|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,887988,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} In August at Hengyang, Bai Chongxi reorganized his troops.{{cite news |title=CHINA: A Matter of Despair|newspaper=TIME|date=Aug 15, 1949|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,888065,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} In October, as the Canton fell to the Communists, who were almost in complete control of China, Bai Chongxi still commanded 200,000 of his elite troops, making a return to [[Guangxi]] for a final stand after covering for Canton.{{cite news |title=CHINA: Next: Chungking|newspaper=TIME|date=Oct 24, 1949|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,805133,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} ==Taiwan== [[File:228 Incident l.jpg|thumb|Bai Chongxi in Taiwan after the [[February 28 Incident]].]] [[File:Bai chongxi grave.jpg|thumb|right|Grave of Bai Chongxi at Muslim Cemetery on Chongde Street, Xinyi District, Taipei]] The riots following the [[February 28 Incident]] of 28 February 1947 that broke out in [[Taiwan]] due to poor governance by the central government appointed officials and the garrison forces caused many casualties of both native Taiwanese and mainland residents. Bai was sent as Chiang Kai-shek's personal representative on a fact finding mission and to help pacify the populace. After a two-week tour, including interviews with various segments of the Taiwan population, Bai made sweeping recommendations, including replacement of the governor, and prosecution of his chief of [[secret police]]. He also granted [[amnesty]] to student violators of peace on the condition that their parents take custody and guarantee subsequent proper behavior. For his forthright actions, native Taiwanese held him in high regard.{{cite news |title=CHINA: Snow Red & Moon Angel|newspaper=TIME|date=Apr 7, 1947|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,804090-2,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} Bai had another falling out with Chiang when he supported General [[Li Zongren]], his fellow Guangxi comrade-in-arms, for the vice presidency in the 1948 general election when Li won against Chiang's hand picked candidate, [[Sun Fo]]. Chiang then removed Bai from the Defense Minister post and assigned him the responsibility for Central and South China. Bai's forces were the last ones to leave the mainland for [[Hainan Island]] and eventually to Taiwan. He served Chief of the General Staff since 1927 until his retirement in 1949. After he came to Taiwan, he was the appointed vice director of the strategic advisory commission in the presidential office.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FWVxAAAAMAAJ&q=bai+chongxi+At+the+end+of+1949,+he+went+to+Taiwan,+where+he+became+the+vice+director+of+the+strategic+advisory+commission+in+the+presidential+office.&dq=bai+chongxi+At+the+end+of+1949,+he+went+to+Taiwan,+where+he+became+the+vice+director+of+the+strategic+advisory+commission+in+the+presidential+office.|title=The autobiography of Kim Ku, Volume 20|author1=Ku Kim |author2=Jongsoo Lee |year=2000|publisher=University Press of America|location=|isbn=0-7618-1685-2|page=366|accessdate=2010-06-28}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FWVxAAAAMAAJ&q=At+the+end+of+1949,+he+went+to+Taiwan,+where+he+became+the+vice+director+of+the+strategic+advisory+commission+in+the+presidential+office&dq=At+the+end+of+1949,+he+went+to+Taiwan,+where+he+became+the+vice+director+of+the+strategic+advisory+commission+in+the+presidential+office|title=The autobiography of Kim Ku, Volume 20|author1=Ku Kim |author2=Jongsoo Lee |year=2000|publisher=University Press of America|location=|isbn=0-7618-1685-2|page=366|accessdate=2010-06-28}} He also continued to serve in the Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang. He reorganized the party from 1950-1952.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r3AJFusMHJwC&pg=PA56&dq=pai+ch'ung-hsi+wife+ma+p'ei-chang#v=onepage&q=pai%20ch'ung-hsi%20wife%20ma%20p'ei-chang&f=false|title=Biographical dictionary of Republican China, Volume 3|author1=Howard L. Boorman |author2=Richard C. Howard |author3=Joseph K. H. Cheng |year=1979|publisher=Columbia University Press|location=New York City|isbn=0-231-08957-0|page=56|accessdate=2010-06-28}} After the Communist victory, some of Bai Chongxi's [[Guangxi]] troops fled to French Indochina where they were detained.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mgFYAAAAMAAJ&q=ma+pu-fang+egypt&dq=ma+pu-fang+egypt|title=Mi Kungmubu Hanʾguk kungnae sanghwang kwallyŏn munsŏ|author=Korea (South). 國防部. 軍事編纂硏究所|year=|publisher=國防部軍事編纂硏究所|location=|isbn=|page=168|accessdate=2010-06-28}} Others went to [[Hainan]] in retreat.{{cite news |title=CHINA: Last Phase|newspaper=TIME|date=Dec 12, 1949|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,854033,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} In 1951, Bai Chongxi made a speech to the entire Muslim world calling for a war against the Soviet Union, claiming that the "imperialist ogre" leader [[Joseph Stalin]] was engineering World War III, and Bai also called upon Muslims to avoid the Indian leader [[Jawaharlal Nehru]], accusing him of being blind to [[Soviet Imperialism|Soviet imperialism]].{{cite news |title=Moslems Urged To Resist Russia|newspaper=Christian Science Monitor|date=25 Sep 1951|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/csmonitor_historic/access/275861742.html?dids=275861742:275861742&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&date=Sep+25%2C+1951&author=&pub=Christian+Science+Monitor&desc=Moslems+Urged+To+Resist+Russia&pqatl=google|accessdate=December 12, 2010}}{{cite news |title=CHINESE ASKS ALL MOSLEMS TO FIGHT REDS|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|date=24 Sep 1951|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/497978032.html?dids=497978032:497978032&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Sep+24%2C+1951&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=CHINESE+ASKS+ALL+MOSLEMS+TO+FIGHT+REDS&pqatl=google|accessdate=December 12, 2010}} He and Chiang never reconciled and he lived in semi-retirement until he died of coronary [[thrombosis]] on 1 December 1966 at the age of 73.{{cite news |title=GEN. PAI IS DEAD; A CHIANG AIDE, 73; Key Leader in Nationalist Army Since 1920's|newspaper=THE NEW YORK TIMES|date=9 Dec 1966|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1966/12/09/archives/gen-pai-is-dead-a-chiang-aide-73-key-leader-in-nationalist-army.html|accessdate=December 12, 2010}}{{cite news |title=Milestones: Dec. 9, 1966|newspaper=TIME|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,898508,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} Bai was then given a military funeral by the government, with a Kuomintang [[Blue Sky with a White Sun]] flag over his coffin.[http://bbs.guilinlife.com/UploadFile/2008-6/200862112291226926.jpg Bai's Funeral]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Bai was buried in the Muslim section of the Liuzhangli (六張犁) Cemetery in [[Taipei]], Taiwan.{{cite web|url=http://blog.rti.org.tw/english/2011/05/17/living-history-in-the-liuzhangli-cemetery-in-taipei/|title=Living History in the Liuzhangli Cemetery in Taipei - Hear in Taiwan|publisher=|accessdate=24 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000126/http://blog.rti.org.tw/english/2011/05/17/living-history-in-the-liuzhangli-cemetery-in-taipei/|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=yes|df=}} ==Personal life== [[File:Former Residence of Bai Chongxi in Nanjing 01 2012-09.JPG|thumb|Bai Chongxi's former residence in [[Nanjing]].]] As a Muslim, he was Chairman of the Chinese Islamic National Salvation Federation, and then the [[Chinese Muslim Association]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BwuSpFiOFfYC&pg=PA86&lpg=PA86&dq=chongxi+muslim#v=onepage&q=chongxi%20muslim&f=false|title=China's Muslim Hui community: migration, settlement and sects |author=Michael Dillon |year=1999 |publisher= Curzon Press |location= Richmond |page=86; 208 |isbn=0-7007-1026-4 |accessdate= 2010-06-28}} Bai Chongxi was a board member of the All-China Inter-religious Association, representing Islam, the other members of the board were a Catholic Bishop, Methodist Bishop, and the Buddhist Abbot [[Taixu]].{{cite news |title=Religion: Chungking Meeting|newspaper=TIME|date=June 14, 1943|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,851822,00.html|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} Bai sent his son [[Pai Hsien-yung]] to Catholic schools in Hong Kong.[http://www.independent.com/news/2006/sep/28/peony-dreams/ Peony Dreams] Retrieved 12-6-2008. During the Northern Expedition, in 1926 in Guangxi, Bai Chongxi led his troops in destroying Buddhist temples and smashing idols, turning the temples into schools and Kuomintang party headquarters.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tCA9AAAAIAAJ&dq=accused+chiang+feudal&q=muslim#v=onepage&q=pai%20smashing%20idols%20decapitating%20statues&f=false|title=Region and nation: the Kwangsi clique in Chinese politics, 1925-1937|author=Diana Lary|year=1974|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=|page=98|isbn=0-521-20204-3|accessdate=2010-06-28}} It was reported that almost all of Buddhist monasteries in Guangxi were destroyed by Bai in this manner. The monks were removed.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LxDUeWdMubkC&pg=PA146&dq=bai+chongxi+buddhist+temples#v=onepage&q=bai%20chongxi%20buddhist%20temples&f=false|title=Toward a modern Chinese Buddhism: Taixu's reforms|author=Don Alvin Pittman|year=2001|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|location=|page=146|isbn=0-8248-2231-5|accessdate=2010-06-28}} Bai led a wave of anti-foreignism in Guangxi, attacking American, European, and other foreigners and missionaries, and generally making the province unsafe for foreigners. Westerners fled from the province, and some Chinese Christians were also attacked as imperialist agents.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tCA9AAAAIAAJ&dq=accused+chiang+feudal&q=muslim#v=snippet&q=missionary%20crowd&f=false|title=Region and nation: the Kwangsi clique in Chinese politics, 1925-1937|author=Diana Lary|year=1974|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=|page=99|isbn=0-521-20204-3|accessdate=2010-06-28}} The three goals of his movement were anti-foreignism, anti-imperialism, and anti-religion. Bai led the anti-religious movement, against superstition. [[Huang Shaoxiong]], also a Kuomintang member of the New Guangxi Clique, supported Bai's campaign, and Huang was a non-Muslim, the anti religious campaign was agreed upon by all Guangxi Kuomintang members, so it may have not had anything to do with Bai's beliefs.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tCA9AAAAIAAJ&dq=accused+chiang+feudal&q=muslim#v=onepage&q=pai's%20as%20a%20moslem%20other%20religions&f=false|title=Region and nation: the Kwangsi clique in Chinese politics, 1925-1937|author=Diana Lary|year=1974|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=|page=99|isbn=0-521-20204-3|accessdate=2010-06-28}} As a Kuomintang member, Bai and the other Guangxi clique members allowed the Communists to continue attacking foreigners and idols, since they shared the goal of expelling the foreign powers from China, but they stopped Communists from initiating social change.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tCA9AAAAIAAJ&dq=accused+chiang+feudal&q=muslim#v=onepage&q=provincial%20kuomintang%20iconoclastic%20foreign&f=false|title=Region and nation: the Kwangsi clique in Chinese politics, 1925-1937|author=Diana Lary|year=1974|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=|page=100|isbn=0-521-20204-3|accessdate=2010-06-28}} British diplomats reported that he also drank [[wine]] and ate [[pork]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O19wAAAAMAAJ&dq=accused+chiang+feudal&q=moslem|title=The Kwangsi way in Kuomintang China, 1931-1939|author=Eugene William Levich|year=1993|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|location=|page=14|isbn=1-56324-200-1|accessdate=2010-06-28}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GTgEPrlfvG4C&dq=chiang+portraits+streets&q=chiang+alientae+stalin#v=snippet&q=pork%20wine&f=false|title=Chiang Kai Shek: China's Generalissimo and the Nation He Lost|author=Jonathan Fenby|year=2005|publisher=Carroll & Graf Publishers|location=|page=117|isbn=0-7867-1484-0|accessdate=2010-06-28}} Bai Chongxi was interested in Xinjiang, a predominately Muslim province. He wanted to resettle disbanded Chinese soldiers there to prevent it from being seized by the [[Soviet Union]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tCA9AAAAIAAJ&dq=accused+chiang+feudal&q=muslim#v=onepage&q=pai%20minority%20tibetans%20british%20foreign&f=false|title=Region and nation: the Kwangsi clique in Chinese politics, 1925-1937|author=Diana Lary|year=1974|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=|page=124|isbn=0-521-20204-3|accessdate=2010-06-28}} Bai personally wanted to lead an expedition to seize back Xinjiang to bring it under Chinese control, in the style that [[Zuo Zongtang]] led during the [[Dungan revolt (1862–1877)|Dungan revolt]]. Bai's partner in the Guangxi clique [[Huang Shaohong]] planned an invasion of Xinjiang. During the [[Kumul Rebellion]] [[Chiang Kai-shek]] was ready to send Huang Shaohong and his expeditionary force which he assembled to assist Muslim General Ma Zhongying against [[Sheng Shicai]], but when Chiang heard about the [[Soviet Invasion of Xinjiang]], he decided to withdraw to avoid an international incident if his troops directly engaged the Soviets, leaving Ma alone with not reinforcements to fight the Red Army. Huang was suspicious of this, suspecting that Chiang feared that the Guangxi clique was take control of Xinjiang rather than Chiang's Nanjing regime.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rsLQdBUgyMUC&dq=ma+lin+muslim&q=ma+zhongying#v=onepage&q=ma%20zhongying%20ally%20xinjiang%20huang%20&f=false|title=Modern China's Ethnic Frontiers: A Journey to the West|author=Hsiao-ting Lin|year=2010|publisher=Taylor & Francis|location=|isbn=0-415-58264-4|page=46|accessdate=2010-06-28}} ==Impact== Bai's reputation as a military strategist was well known.[[Barbara Tuchman]]'s book ''Stilwell and American Experience in China'' [[Evans Carlson]], a United States Marine Corps colonel, noted that Bai "was considered by many to be the keenest of Chinese military men." [[Edgar Snow]] went even further, calling him "one of the most intelligent and efficient commanders boasted by any army in the world." Bai is the father of [[Kenneth Hsien-yung Pai]], Chinese author and playwright now living in the United States. Bai and his wife had ten children, three girls and seven boys.[http://a2.att.hudong.com/44/87/01300000203503125320877056306_s.jpg Picture of Bai and his Wife with their Children] Their names are Patsy, Diana, Daniel, Richard, Alfred, Amy, David, Kenneth, Robert and Charlie. He married his wife Ma P'ei-chang in 1925. Of his ten children, three are still living, scattered across America and Taiwan. Taipei Mayor [[Hau Lung-pin]] announced in March 2013 that Bai's tomb will form the basis for a Muslim cultural area and Taiwan historical park.http://www.taiwantoday.tw/ct.asp?xItem=202548&CtNode=445
