revision.comment: /* Rumors of early death */ Three is enough.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Infobox historical event |Event_Name = Death of Hugo Chávez |Image_Name = File:Hugo Chavez hearse.jpg |Image_Caption = Hearse carrying Hugo Chávez's remains |AKA = |Participants = |Location = [[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]] |Date = 5 March 2013 |cause = Cancer |burial = [[Cuartel de la Montaña]] ([[:es:Cuartel de la Montaña (Caracas)|es]]), }} [[Hugo Chávez]], the [[List of Presidents of Venezuela#Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela .281999.E2.80.93present.29|62nd President of Venezuela]], died on 5 March 2013 at the age of 58. His death triggered a [[Venezuelan presidential election, 2013|presidential election]] which was constitutionally required to be called within 30 days. [[Nicolás Maduro]] served as interim president following Chávez's death until 14 April, because the Vice President did not want to take charge of the country as Chávez had nominated Nicolas Maduro as a successor.<ref>[http://news.sky.com/story/1078222/venezuela-nicolas-maduro-elected-president "Nicolas Maduro Elected President", from Sky News]</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Foreign Minister: VP Maduro is Interim President |url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/foreign-minister-vp-maduro-interim-president |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=6 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309024846/http://bigstory.ap.org/article/foreign-minister-vp-maduro-interim-president |archivedate= 9 March 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Chávez was first elected as president in [[Venezuelan presidential election, 1998|1998]] and was re-elected in [[Venezuelan presidential election, 2000|2000]], [[Venezuelan presidential election, 2006|2006]] and finally in [[Venezuelan presidential election, 2012|2012]]. However, Chávez was unable to be sworn in for a fourth term after the 2012 election due to his illness.
==Illness and death== [[File:Noveno encuentro presidencial Ecuador - Venezuela (5809138669).jpg|250px|thumbnail|right|Chávez walking with a cane accompanied by [[Rafael Correa]] in Caracas in July 2011, shortly after his first cancer surgery.]] Chávez was diagnosed with cancer following the discovery of a mass in his pelvic region in June 2011. He traveled to Havana, Cuba where he underwent a surgical operation to remove a malignant cancerous tissue mass 'about the size of a baseball' from his waist. He underwent a second surgical operation in Venezuela one month later. Over the next 12 months, he followed a cycle of chemotherapy. The type of cancer Chávez was diagnosed with was never made public which fueled speculation over his condition (with speculations from being [[prostate cancer]] to [[colon cancer]] among others). Following the [[Venezuelan presidential election, 2012|presidential election]] in October 2012 (where he was re-elected to a fourth term), he went to Cuba for more treatment and then returned to Venezuela and stayed at a Caracas army hospital for one week until his death. Successive announcements of his return and updates of his health were criticised by the country's opposition that the population were unaware of his health and location. The fact that the cancer had metastasised was not made public during the campaign, and strongly denied by Government officers. After the first lung infection (pneumonia) in the last stages of his life, Chávez was intubated nearing the end of December. His breathing worsened until his death was announced at 16:25 [[Venezuelan Standard Time|VET]] (20:55 [[UTC]]) on 5 March 2013, almost two years after he was first diagnosed.{{citation needed|date=May 2017}}
Vice-president [[Nicolás Maduro]] announced Chávez's death on a mandatory television ''cadena'' (a decree forcing all broadcasters to relay State television content).<ref name=dindon>{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2013/03/05/venezuelan-president-hugo-chavez-dead-vp-says/|title=Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez dead, VP says|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref> In an emotional eulogy Maduro said: "Let there be no weakness, no violence. Let there be no hate. In our hearts there should only be one feeling: Love."<ref name="bbc"/> Maduro indicated that Chávez had died "after battling a tough illness for nearly two years."<ref name=dindon/> He added that police and troops would be deployed across the country 'to guarantee the peace.' The head of the presidential guard said Chávez died of a massive heart attack after great suffering and had inaudibly mouthed his desire to live. In an interview to the [[Associated Press]] he said that Chávez could not speak but he said it with his lips ... "I don't want to die. Please don't let me die".<ref>{{cite news|first=Fabiola|last=Sanchez|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/general-heart-attack-killed-suffering-chavez-18672150|title=General: Heart Attack Killed a Suffering Chavez|publisher=ABC News|date=7 March 2013|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref> The [[BBC]] reported isolated incidents of violence following the announcement of Chávez's death. Although pro-Chavez supporters attacked and burned tents of students who had camped demanding more official information about Chávez's health, there were no reported injuries.<ref name="bbc"/> Vice-President Maduro indicated he had "no doubt" of foul play by "the historical enemies of our fatherland" behind Chávez's illness and death.<ref name=dindon/> Defence Minister [[Diego Morelo Bellavia]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rnv.gov.ve/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=946%3Apresident-chavez-appoints-diego-morelo-bellavia-as-defense-minister&Itemid=27 |title=President Chavez appoints Diego Morelo Bellavia as defense minister |publisher=Rnv.gov.ve |accessdate=8 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160204103329/http://www.rnv.gov.ve/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=946%3Apresident-chavez-appoints-diego-morelo-bellavia-as-defense-minister&Itemid=27 |archivedate=4 February 2016 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> said that the "Bolivarian" armed forces would be loyal to the vice president and National Assembly and urged supporters and opposition to remain calm.<ref name="bbc">{{cite news|author=Irene Caselli |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21682247 |title=Venezuelans mourn President Hugo Chavez |publisher=BBC |accessdate=6 March 2013 |date=6 March 2013}}</ref>
== Early death rumours == After defecting from Venezuela, former bodyguard for Chávez, [[Leamsy Salazar]], stated that he died in December 2012, months before his date was officially announced.<ref name="INFOBAEjan2015">{{cite news|url=http://www.infobae.com/2015/01/29/1623711-el-jefe-seguridad-chavez-declaro-que-el-caudillo-murio-dos-meses-antes-la-fecha-oficial|title=El jefe de Seguridad de Chávez declaró que el caudillo murió dos meses antes de la fecha oficial|date=29 January 2015|accessdate=30 January 2015|agency=[[Infobae]]}}</ref>
In July 2018, former Attorney General [[Luisa Ortega Díaz]] also said that Chávez had actually died in December 2012 and the announcement of his death was delayed for political reasons. In an interview cited by Venezuelan daily [[El Nacional (Caracas)|''El Nacional'']], the former Chávez supporter said that the Venezuelan president died on 28 December, but his closest allies decided to delay the announcement and never submitted the death certificate to the Office of the Attorney General.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.el-nacional.com/noticias/politica/luisa-ortega-diaz-revelo-que-diosdado-cabello-llamo-morir-chavez_243720|title=Diosdado Cabello a Luisa Ortega Díaz: "vente que Chávez se murió"|last=Web|first=El Nacional|date=2018-07-12|work=El Nacional|access-date=2018-07-12|language=es}}</ref>
The supposed delay in announcing Chávez's death raised concerns that laws signed in his name during that period were forged for political purposes.<ref name="INFOBAEjan2015" />
== Reactions ==
===Domestic=== [[File:Bandera media asta chavez cortejo funebre 06032013.JPG|thumb|right|Venezuelan flag at half-mast in mourning for the death of President Chávez]] Thousands of people flooded the streets of the capital [[Caracas]]. Many cried and hugged in public shows of emotion. Women were weeping at [[Miraflores Palace]]. With a mixture of joy and sadness Chávez supporters shared their impressions after him a last farewell: "That man emanates a force forward and his face says my people.".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.noticias24.com/venezuela/noticia/154762/la-emocion-de-los-venezolanos-que-vieron-a-chavez-haremos-cumplir-la-constitucion-junto-a-maduro/|title=La emoción del pueblo que vio a Chávez: 'Haremos cumplir la Constitución junto a Maduro'|agency=Noticias24|date=7 March 2013|accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> People left work for the day upon hearing the news, shops and offices shut and cars and buses filled the streets.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/03/05/3268804/venezuelans-pour-into-streets.html#morer|title=Venezuelans pour into streets to mourn Hugo Chavez|agency=Associated Press|work=The Miami Herald|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref>
Opposition leader and opponent in the 2012 election, [[Henrique Capriles]], called on the government to "act in strict accordance with its [[Constitution of Venezuela|constitutional duties]]." He also added his condolences to Chávez's family saying "we were adversaries, but never enemies".<ref name="bbc"/> Acting President Nicolás Maduro said he believed Chávez was assassinated by Venezuela's "historical enemies" (widely assumed to mean the United States), and that a "scientific commission" would investigate this possibility. The [[United States Department of State|US State Department]] denied any American involvement, calling the claim "absurd".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/03/05/maduro-promises-to-investigate-chavez-assassination/ |title=Maduro promises to investigate Chavez 'assassination'|work=The Washington Post |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref>
On the first anniversary of Chavez's death, tens of thousands of his supporters marched through cities across Venezuela. This was coupled with the [[2014 Venezuelan protests]] featuring pro and anti-government demonstrations.<ref>http://www.aljazeera.com/news/americas/2014/03/venezuela-chavistas-remember-late-leader-201435154623495164.html</ref>
===Foreign=== UN Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]]'s office issued a statement expressing condolences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/un-secretary-general-ban-kimoon-hails-hugo-chavezs-work-for-poor/1083869/ |title=UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon hails Hugo Chavez's work for poor |work=The Indian Express |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref>
Reactions within the Americas by citizens<!--as opposed to political figures--> occurred outside Venezuela's embassies in Honduras, El Salvador, Chile and Ecuador.<ref name="latamppl"/> Spanish citizens expressed their support and solidarity to the people of Venezuela, by concentrating on Wednesday afternoon in the vicinity of the Plaza Puerta del Sol in Madrid (capital), to express in slogans that "Chávez's legacy will remain far beyond of his death."<ref>{{cite web|title=espanoles-se-concentran-en-madrid-en-solidaridad-al-pueblo-venezolano|url=http://www.telesurtv.net/articulos/2013/03/06/espanoles-se-concentran-en-madrid-en-solidaridad-al-pueblo-venezolano-1545.html|publisher=telesurtv.net|accessdate=9 March 2013}}</ref>
====Latin America and the Caribbean==== OAS Secretary General [[José Miguel Insulza]] ordered the body's flags to be flown at half-mast and the convening of a special meeting of the Permanent Council in memory of Chávez.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oas.org/en/media_center/press_release.asp?sCodigo=E-074/13 |title=Press Releases :: E-074/13 |publisher=OAS |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref>
After announcing Hugo Chávez's death, Bolivian president [[Evo Morales]] broke down and cried on national television while paying tribute to Chávez;<ref>{{cite news |first=Peter |last=Orsi |url=http://www.miamiherald.com/2013/03/05/3268596/chavez-death-echoes-with-leftists.html |title=Chavez death echoes with leftists worldwide |agency=Associated Press |work=The Miami Herald |date=5 March 2013 |accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref> Morales then decreed seven days of mourning in Bolivia after Chávez's death.<ref name=Guardian-SA-Leaders>{{cite news |last=Watts |first=Jonathan |title=Tributes to Hugo Chávez flow from South American leaders |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/mar/06/tributes-hugo-chavez-south-american |accessdate=6 March 2013 |date=6 March 2013 |work=The Guardian |location=Buenos Aires }}</ref> Brazilian president [[Dilma Rousseff]], who had cancelled a scheduled trip to Argentina to meet President Kirchner, led a minute of silence in [[Brasília]].<ref name="lasegunda.com">{{cite news |title=Brasil decreta tres días de duelo nacional en por muerte de Chávez |url=http://www.lasegunda.com/noticias/internacional/2013/03/827727/brasil-decreta-tres-dias-de-duelo-nacional-en-por-muerte-de-chavez |accessdate=6 March 2013 |newspaper=La Segunda |date=6 March 2013 |agency=Agencia EFE |location=BRASILIA |language=Spanish}}</ref> Rousseff decreed three days of mourning.<ref name="lasegunda.com"/> Rousseff's predecessor, [[Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva]], also expressed grief.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/brazils-rousseff-says-chavezs-death-irreparable-loss/article9323390/|title=Brazil's Rousseff says Chavez's death 'irreparable loss'|agency=Agence France-Presse|work=The Globe and Mail|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=5 March 2013|location=Toronto}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=U.S. politicians, world leaders react to the death of Hugo Chavez|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/03/05/u-s-politicians-world-leaders-react-to-the-death-of-hugo-chavez/|newspaper=The Washington Post|accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> Salvadorean president [[Mauricio Funes]] and Chilean president [[Sebastián Piñera]] both praised Chávez's strong character,<ref name="latamppl">{{cite news |url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/766251.shtml |title=People around world mourn Hugo Chavez |work=Global Times |location=China |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref><ref name="Reuters"/> and the Chilean government declared three days of national mourning for Chávez.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.cooperativa.cl/noticias/mundo/venezuela/hugo-chavez/gobierno-de-chile-decreto-tres-dias-de-duelo-nacional-por-muerte-de-hugo-chavez/2013-03-06/101748.html |title=Gobierno de Chile decretó tres días de duelo nacional por muerte de Hugo Chávez |work=Radio Cooperativa |location=Santiago, Chile |date=6 March 2013 |language=Spanish |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref>
The Cuban Council of State decreed two days of official mourning, from 6 am on 6 March to midnight 7 March, and a third day of national mourning on 8 March.<ref name=Guardian-SA-Leaders/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vtv.gob.ve/articulos/2013/03/05/cuba-declara-duelo-oficial-y-nacional-por-fallecimiento-del-presidente-chavez-6752.html|title=Cuba declara duelo oficial y nacional por fallecimiento del Presidente Chávez|accessdate=6 March 2013|date=5 March 2013|agency=Venezolana de Televisión|location=Havana|language=Spanish|quote=DECLARA EL CONSEJO DE ESTADO DUELO OFICIAL Y DUELO NACIONAL Con motivo del fallecimiento del compañero Hugo Rafael Chávez Frías, Presidente de la República Bolivariana de Venezuela, el Consejo de Estado de la República de Cuba ha decretado lo siguiente: Primero: Declarar Duelo Oficial a partir de las 6:00 a.m. del día 6 de marzo, hasta las 12:00 de la noche del día 7 de marzo. Segundo: Declarar Duelo Nacional el día 8 de marzo. Mientras esté vigente el Duelo Oficial, la bandera nacional será izada a media asta en los edificios públicos y establecimientos militares. Durante la vigencia del Duelo Nacional, quedan suspendidos todos los espectáculos públicos y actividades festivas.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022031428/http://www.vtv.gob.ve/articulos/2013/03/05/cuba-declara-duelo-oficial-y-nacional-por-fallecimiento-del-presidente-chavez-6752.html|archivedate=22 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=CNN/> The presidents of Dominican Republic, Haiti,<ref name=DOM-HAT>{{cite news |title=Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez dies |publisher=Estrategia y Negocios |date=6 March 2013 |url=http://www.estrategiaynegocios.net/2013/03/06/republica-dominicana-y-haiti-decretan-duelo-por-muerte-de-chavez/ |agency= Agence France-Presse |language=Spanish |accessdate=6 March 2013 |quote=El presidente de Haití, Michel Martelly, decretó tres días de duelo nacional desde este miércoles tras la muerte de su colega venezolano Hugo Chávez, a quien calificó como "un hermano más que un amigo". "El presidente Hugo Chávez fue uno de los mayores partidarios que Haití haya tenido. Nunca perdió la oportunidad de recordar su amor por Haití. Era más que un amigo, un hermano", dijo Martelly desde el palacio presidencial, ante todo el gobierno y el embajador de Venezuela en Puerto Príncipe.}}</ref> Uruguay and Ecuador all decreed three days of mourning for Chávez.<ref name=CNN>{{cite news |title=Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez dies |publisher=CNN |date=6 March 2013 |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/03/05/world/americas/venezuela-chavez-main/index.html |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=Uruguay>{{cite news|title=Uruguay decreta tres días de duelo por la muerte del presidente venezolano|url=http://www.el-nacional.com/mundo/Uruguay-decreta-muerte-presidente-venezolano_0_148786298.html|work=El Nacional|date=6 March 2013|accessdate=6 March 2013|publisher=Agencia EFE|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309035446/http://www.el-nacional.com/mundo/Uruguay-decreta-muerte-presidente-venezolano_0_148786298.html|archivedate=9 March 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Nicaraguan president [[Daniel Ortega]] declared seven days of mourning.<ref>{{cite news|title=Gobierno de Nicaragua decreta siete días de Duelo Nacional por fallecimiento de Presidente Chávez|url=http://www.el19digital.com/index.php?option=com_content&id=50806|accessdate=6 March 2013|date=6 March 2013|agency=El 19 Digital|language=Spanish|quote=El Gobierno del Presidente Daniel Ortega y la Compañera Rosario Murillo, decretó siete días de Duelo Nacional por el fallecimiento en Caracas del líder bolivariano, Comandante Hugo Chávez Frías.}}</ref> Colombian president [[Juan Manuel Santos]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://wsp.presidencia.gov.co/Prensa/2013/Marzo/Paginas/20130305_07.aspx|title='Lamento profundamente la muerte del Presidente Chávez': Presidente Santos|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Presidencia Colombiana|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref> Mexican president [[Enrique Peña Nieto]]{{citation needed|date=July 2016}}<!-- WP:RS needed; removed link to WP:SPS (Twitter, FB, WP)--> lamented the death of Chávez; The Mexican Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a press release expressing condolences and "our feeling of fraternity".<ref>{{cite news|title=EL GOBIERNO DE MÉXICO EXPRESA CONDOLENCIAS POR EL FALLECIMIENTO DEL PRESIDENTE CHÁVEZ |language=Spanish |url=http://saladeprensa.sre.gob.mx/index.php/es/comunicados/2368-052 |accessdate=6 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309104320/http://saladeprensa.sre.gob.mx/index.php/es/comunicados/2368-052 |archivedate= 9 March 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> Colombia ordered its 15 consulates in Venezuela temporarily closed to observe the days of mourning. Guyanan president [[Donald Ramotar]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stabroeknews.com/2013/news/stories/03/06/chavez-was-great-friend-of-guyana-ramotar/ |title=Chavez was great friend of Guyana |publisher=Stabroek News |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> Guatemalan president [[Otto Pérez Molina]],<ref name=Guatemala>{{cite news|title=Presidente Pérez Molina exalta figura política de gobernante Hugo Chávez |publisher=CGobierno de Guatemala |language=Spanish |date=5 March 2013 |url=http://guatemala.gob.gt/index.php/2011-08-04-18-06-26/item/3129-presidente-p%C3%A9rez-molina-exalta-figura-pol%C3%ADtica-de-gobernante-hugo-ch%C3%A1vez |accessdate=6 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130307200816/http://www.guatemala.gob.gt/index.php/2011-08-04-18-06-26/item/3129-presidente-p%C3%A9rez-molina-exalta-figura-pol%C3%ADtica-de-gobernante-hugo-ch%C3%A1vez |archivedate= 7 March 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> and the President of Suriname [[Desi Bouterse]] regretted losing a "friend". The [[Government of Suriname]] declared Friday a day of national mourning. Ramotar and Honduran president [[Porfirio Lobo]] praised Chavez for his contribution to regional integration; the [[National Congress of Honduras]] addressed a minute of silence.<ref>{{cite web |title=Honduras lamenta profundamente la muerte de Chávez |trans-title=Reaction to the death of Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez |url= http://laprensa.hn/Secciones-Principales/Mundo/America-Latina/Honduras-lamenta-profundamente-la-muerte-de-Chavez |publisher=La Prensa |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref>
Trinidad and Tobago<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stabroeknews.com/2013/news/regional/03/06/tt-pm-chavez-broke-new-ground/ |title=T&T PM: Chavez broke new ground |publisher=Stabroek News |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> and Jamaica said that special arrangements would be made for an official tribute to Chávez.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stabroeknews.com/2013/news/regional/03/06/jamaica-parliament-pays-tribute-to-chavez/ |title=Jamaica Parliament pays tribute to Chavez |publisher=Stabroek News |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> Uruguay announced that President [[José Mujica]] was in Argentina for a summit when Chávez died, but that he would fly to Caracas with Argentine President Cristina Kirchner to attend the funeral.<ref name=Infonews/> Argentina declared three days of mourning<ref name=Infonews>{{cite news|title=Cristina llégo a Caracas y hay tres días de duelo|url=http://www.infonews.com/2013/03/05/politica-63924-cristina-llego-a-caracas-y-hay-tres-dias-de-duelo.php|accessdate=6 March 2013|agency=Infonews|language=Spanish}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Cristina Kirchner decretó tres días de duelo y viajará a Caracas|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1560407-cristina-kirchner-suspendio-un-acto-por-la-muerte-del-venezolano|newspaper=La Nación|language=Spanish|accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> Suriname declared Friday a day of mourning.
====North America==== Canadian prime minister [[Stephen Harper]] offered his condolences;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pm.gc.ca/eng/media.asp?category=3&featureId=6&pageId=49&id=5341 |title=Statement by the Prime Minister of Canada on the death of Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez Frías – Prime Minister of Canada |publisher=pm.gc.ca |accessdate=6 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130308142230/http://pm.gc.ca/eng/media.asp?category=3&featureId=6&pageId=49&id=5341 |archivedate= 8 March 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> former Prime Minister [[Jean Chrétien]] eulogised in a televised interview.<ref name="Reuters">{{cite news|title=Reaction to the death of Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/06/us-venezuela-chavez-reaction-idUSBRE92502R20130306|agency=Reuters|accessdate=6 March 2013|date=6 March 2013|author=Carlos Garcia Rawlins}}</ref>
Suggestions of American foul play,<ref name="dindon"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Hugo Chávez, Venezuelan President, Dead at 58|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/hugo-chavez-dead-president-venezuela-58-died-cancer/story?id=16198379|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref> implying that Chávez had been poisoned or somehow infected with cancer (arguing a plot reminiscent to the [[Cause of Yasser Arafat's death#Theories about the cause of death|Yasser Arafat death controversy]] and the [[Assassination attempts on Fidel Castro#Castro assassination attempts|attempts against Fidel Castro]]),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2013/03/05/venezuela-expels-us-diplomat-vice-president-claims-hugo-chavez-was-poisoned/ |title=Venezuela Expels 2 US Diplomats; Vice President Claims Hugo Chávez was Poisoned | Fox News Latino |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=5 March 2013|accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/Flash.aspx/263658 |title=Venezuelan VP: Chávez was Poisoned – Latest News Briefs |publisher=Arutz Sheva |accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Cawthorne |first=Andrew |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/05/us-venezuela-chavez-idUSBRE92405420130305 |title=Venezuela's Hugo Chávez dies from cancer |agency=Reuters |date=5 March 2013|accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref> were vehemently denied by the [[United States Department of State|U.S. Department of State]] as "absurd".<ref name="StateDeptDeath">{{cite news | url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1743752/US-rejects-Venezuelas-conspiracy-claims | title=S rejects Venezuela's conspiracy claims | date=5 March 2013 | agency=Agence France-Presse | accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref>
In Miami, some Venezuelans joyfully celebrated Chavez's death, and were cautiously optimistic of new elections for Chávez's successor; an estimated 189,219 Venezuelans live in the United States, most of whom are anti-Chavez.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chavez Death: Venezuelans in U.S. Hopeful of Change |author=Christine Armario |author2=Gillian Flaccus |author3=Claudia Torrens |author4=Steve LeBlanc |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_CHAVEZ_VENEZUELANS_IN_AMERICA?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2013-03-06-05-37-20 |agency=Associated Press |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=12 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130309014220/http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_CHAVEZ_VENEZUELANS_IN_AMERICA?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2013-03-06-05-37-20 |archivedate= 9 March 2013 |df=dmy }}<br/>{{cite news|title=After Hugo Chavez's Death, Venezuelan Expatriates Ponder a Return to Homeland |author=Vanessa Rodriguez |url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/politics/2013/03/08/after-hugo-chavez-death-venezuelan-expatriates-ponder-return-to-homeland/ |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=8 March 2013 |accessdate=12 March 2013 }}<br/>{{cite news|title=U.S. reaction to Chavez's death: from mourning to celebration |author=Tom Watkins |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/03/05/us/venezuela-us-react |publisher=CNN |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=12 March 2013 }}<br/>{{cite AV media|year=2013 |title=Venezuelans celebrate Hugo Chavez's death in South Florida |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oQiFyq-e1Xk |accessdate=12 March 2013 |work=[[The Miami Herald]] }}<br/>{{cite news|title=Venezuelans in Miami React To Chavez's Death |url=http://abcnews.go.com/ABC_Univision/video/venezuelans-miami-react-chavezs-death-18662446 |publisher=ABC News |date=5 March 2013 |accessdate=11 March 2013 }}</ref> United States President [[Barack Obama]] reaffirmed the support of the US for the Venezuelan people and its interest in developing a constructive relationship with the Venezuelan government.<ref name="Reuters"/> Former president [[Jimmy Carter]] complimented Chávez's commitment to improving the lives of Venezuelans. According to a statement posted at the [[Carter Center]] website, Carter and his wife [[Rosalynn Carter|Rosalynn]] "came to know a man who expressed a vision to bring profound changes to his country to benefit especially those people who had felt neglected and marginalized."<ref>{{cite web|title=Carter statement lauds Chavez|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/mar/5/carter-statement-lauds-chavez/|work=The Washington Times|accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref>
====Africa==== [[Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma]], who chairs the African Union Commission, conveyed her condolence to the family, government and people of Venezuela.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.int/en/content/message-condolence-passing-president-hugo-chavez-frias |title=Message of Condolence on the passing of President Hugo Chavez Frias |date=6 March 2013 |publisher=[[African Union]] |accessdate=11 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022095035/http://www.au.int/en/content/message-condolence-passing-president-hugo-chavez-frias |archivedate=22 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> The organisation observed a minute of silence at the A.U. headquarters on 8 March during the celebration of the International Women's Day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.int/en/content/african-union-commission-observes-minutes-silence-late-president-hugo-chavez-venezuela-cel-2 |title=African Union Commission Observes Minutes of Silence for late President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela at celebration of International Women's Day |date=8 March 2013 |publisher=[[African Union]] |accessdate=11 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130731125300/http://au.int/en/content/african-union-commission-observes-minutes-silence-late-president-hugo-chavez-venezuela-cel-2 |archivedate=31 July 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Algerian president [[Abdelaziz Bouteflika]],<ref>[http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/766477.shtml Algerian president pays tribute to late Hugo Chavez]. ''[[Xinhua News Agency]]''. 7 March 2013.</ref> Gambian president [[Yahya Jammeh]],<ref name=observergm/> Mauritanian president [[Mohamed Ould Abdelaziz]],<ref>[http://www.afriquejet.com/201303083284/Venezuela-Mauritanian-president-consoles-Venezuela-on-Hugo-Chavez.html Venezuela: Mauritanian president consoles Venezuela on Hugo Chavez]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}. '' Actualité Economie Finances Sports''. 8 March 2013.</ref> Sahrawi Republic president [[Mohamed Abdelaziz (Sahrawi politician)|Mohamed Abdelaziz]],<ref>{{cite web|title=President of Republic expresses his 'sincere condolences' to the Vice President of Venezuela, Nicolas Maduro following the death of Hugo Chavez |url=http://www.spsrasd.info/en/content/president-republic-expresses-his-sincere-condolences-vice-president-venezuela-nicolas-maduro |publisher=SPS |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=8 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022061223/http://www.spsrasd.info/en/content/president-republic-expresses-his-sincere-condolences-vice-president-venezuela-nicolas-maduro |archivedate=22 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> South African president [[Jacob Zuma]],<ref name = "SA Reaction">{{cite web|author=Sapa |url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/politics/2013/03/06/zuma-sends-condolences-to-venezuela |title=Zuma sends condolences to Venezuela |publisher=Times LIVE |date=2 February 1999 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> Sudanese president [[Omar al-Bashir]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Hugo Chavez: Global reaction|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21678114|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=6 March 2013}}</ref> Tanzanian president [[Jakaya Kikwete]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynews.co.tz/index.php/local-news/15277-kikwete-mourns-chavez |title=Kikwete mourns Chavez |date=7 March 2013 |work=[[Daily News (Tanzania)|Daily News]] |accessdate=10 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022035555/http://www.dailynews.co.tz/index.php/local-news/15277-kikwete-mourns-chavez |archivedate=22 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> all expressed their sorrow and offered their "deepest condolences". Gambia's president [[Yahya Jammeh]] proclaimed two national prayer days at mosques and churches for Chavez, on 8 and 10 March 2013.<ref name=observergm>[http://observer.gm/africa/gambia/article/gambia-sends-condolence-to-venezuela-on-chavezs-demise Gambia sends condolence to Venezuela on Chavez’s demise] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022032729/http://observer.gm/africa/gambia/article/gambia-sends-condolence-to-venezuela-on-chavezs-demise |date=22 October 2013 }}. ''[[The Daily Observer]]'', 7 March 2013</ref> The Sahrawi government declared a day of national mourning.<ref name="MinisterSPS">{{cite web|title=Minister for Latin America represents President of Republic in Chávez funeral |url=http://www.spsrasd.info/en/content/minister-latin-america-represents-president-republic-ch%C3%A1vez-funeral |publisher=SPS |date=8 March 2013 |accessdate=11 December 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213155031/http://www.spsrasd.info/en/content/minister-latin-america-represents-president-republic-ch%C3%A1vez-funeral |archivedate=13 December 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref>
====Asia==== Afghanistan president [[Hamid Karzai]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://president.gov.af/en/news/18083 |title=President Karzai Calls Hugo Chavez death a great loss – Office of the President |publisher=President.gov.af |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=15 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022055800/http://president.gov.af/en/news/18083 |archivedate=22 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> President of Armenia [[Serzh Sargsyan]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/news/148807/ |title=Armenian President offers condolences on Hugo Chávez death |publisher=PanArmenian.net |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> Azerbaijani president [[Ilham Aliyev]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.president.az/articles/7527|title=Venesuela Bolivar Respublikasının Vitse-prezidenti Zati-aliləri cənab Nikolas Maduro Morosa |publisher=president.az |language=Azerbaijani |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> Chinese president [[Hu Jintao]] and Communist Party of China general secretary [[Xi Jinping]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/766293.shtml |title=China expresses condolences on Chavez's death |work=Global Times |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> deputy director-general of the Taiwanese Foreign Ministry Calvin Ho,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://focustaiwan.tw/ShowNews/WebNews_Detail.aspx?Type=aALL&ID=201303060019 |title=Taiwan mourns death of Venezuela's president |publisher=focustaiwan.tw |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> Indian prime minister [[Manmohan Singh]] issued statements of "heartfelt condolences".<ref>{{cite web |title=Manmohan Singh condoles death of Hugo Chavez |work=Daily News and Analysis |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_manmohan-singh-condoles-death-of-hugo-chavez_1807932 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref>
Pakistan president [[Asif Ali Zardari]] and Prime Minister [[Raja Pervaiz Ashraf]], President of the Palestinian National Authority [[Mahmoud Abbas]],<ref name="Haaretz"/> Turkmenistan president [[Gurbanguly Berdymukhamedov]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://turkmenistan.gov.tm/_eng/?id=1967 |title=President of Turkmenistan expresses his condolences over the death of President of Venezuela Hugo Chavez |publisher=Turkmenistan.gov.tm |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> Vietnamese leaders – including Party general secretary [[Nguyễn Phú Trọng]], Prime Minister [[Nguyễn Tấn Dũng]], and National Assembly chairman [[Nguyễn Sinh Hùng]] – also expressed condolences; some lauded Chavez's achievements.<ref>{{cite web|title=Việt Nam chia buồn với Venezuela|url=http://tuoitre.vn/Chinh-tri-Xa-hoi/536834/viet-nam-chia-buon-voi-venezuela.html|work=Tuổi Trẻ|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref> Memorial services were scheduled to be held in [[Ramallah]] and other cities in the [[West Bank]] and senior Palestinian officials paid their respects at the Venezuelan Embassy in Ramallah.<ref name="Haaretz">{{cite news|title=Palestinians grieve over death of Venezuela's Hugo Chavez|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/middle-east/palestinians-grieve-over-death-of-venezuela-s-hugo-chavez.premium-1.507719|work=Haaretz|first=Jack |last=Khoury|date=6 March 2013}}</ref> In [[Gaza City]] streets were decorated with Venezuelan flags and posters of Chavez.<ref name="Akhbar">[http://english.al-akhbar.com/content/thousands-palestinians-pay-tribute-chavez Thousands of Palestinians pay tribute to Chavez]. ''[[Al Akhbar (Lebanon)|Al Akhbar]]''. Originally published by [[Agence France-Presse]]. 7 March 2013.</ref> [[Hamas]], the ''de facto'' government of the Gaza Strip, lauded Chávez as a "great leader";<ref name="Akhbar"/> The [[Syrian Arab News Agency]] paid homage to Chávez for taking "an honourable stance regarding the conspiracy against Syria".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20130306-damascus-hails-honourable-chavez-stance-conflict |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130411001306/http://www.france24.com/en/20130306-damascus-hails-honourable-chavez-stance-conflict |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 April 2013 |title=Damascus hails 'honourable' Chavez stance on conflict |publisher=FRANCE 24 |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=6 March 2013 }}</ref> Iran declared a day of national mourning.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/06/us-venezuela-chavez-iran-idUSBRE9250CQ20130306|title=Iran declares day of mourning for anti-US ally Chavez|agency=Reuters|date=6 March 2013|accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref>
====Europe==== In the European Union, European Council President [[Herman Van Rompuy]] and European Commission President [[José Manuel Barroso]] said that they had received the news of Chávez's death with "sadness."<ref>{{cite news |title=Reactions to Death: Chávez Showed 'Will to Fight for Justice' |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=6 March 2013 |url= http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/mixed-reactions-to-death-of-venezuelan-president-hugo-chavez-a-887211.html |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> French president [[François Hollande]]<ref>[http://www.liberation.fr/politiques/2013/03/06/hollande-chavez-a-profondement-marque-l-histoire-de-son-pays_886580 "Hollande: Chavez a «profondément marqué l'histoire de son pays»"], ''[[Libération]]'', 6 March 2013</ref> and British foreign secretary [[William Hague]] were "saddened".<ref name="Reuters"/> Irish president [[Michael D. Higgins]] sent condolences,<ref name="eire">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/politicians-pay-tribute-to-chavez-29111743.html|title=Politicians pay tribute to Chavez |work=Irish Independent |accessdate=6 March 2013|date=6 March 2013}}</ref> [[Sinn Féin]] leader [[Gerry Adams]] also paid tribute.<ref name="eire"/> Italian president [[Giorgio Napolitano]] ("painful")<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.primapaginanews.it/dettaglio_articolo.asp?id=149027&ctg=3 |title=Prima Pagina News – Morte Chavez, messaggio di cordoglio di Napolitano |publisher=Primapaginanews.it |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> The [[Spanish government]] extended its condolences,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.maec.es/es/MenuPpal/Actualidad/Comunicados/Paginas/038comunicado20130306.aspx |title=038-2013. FALLECIMIENTO DE HUGO CHÁVEZ |publisher=Ministerio de Asuntos Exteriores y de Cooperación de España |language=Spanish |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=6 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130311131754/http://www.maec.es/es/MenuPpal/Actualidad/Comunicados/Paginas/038comunicado20130306.aspx |archivedate=11 March 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> as did Portuguese president [[Aníbal Cavaco Silva]] sent condolences,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presidencia.pt/?idc=18&idi=71598 |title=Presidente da República enviou condolências (President of the Republic expressed condolences in letter |publisher=Presidencia.pt |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> whilst Swedish PM [[Fredrik Reinfeldt]] stated that Chávez "undeniably affected his country and the entire region" and hoped for greater democracy and respect for human rights in Venezuela;<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news |url=http://www.svd.se/nyheter/inrikes/reinfeldt-hoppas-pa-forandring_7970216.svd |title=Reinfeldt hoppas på förändring |work=Svenska Dagbladet |language=Swedish |date=7 March 2013 |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> Foreign minister [[Carl Bildt]] criticized his policies,{{citation needed|date=July 2016}}<!-- WP:RS needed; removed link to WP:SPS (Twitter, FB, WP)-->{{citation needed|date=July 2016}}<!-- WP:RS needed; removed link to WP:SPS (Twitter, FB, WP)--> saying that Chávez had "plunder[ed] the oil wealth of [his] country".<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
President of Russia [[Vladimir Putin]] and prime minister [[Dmitry Medvedev]] expressed their "sincere condolences"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2013_03_06/Putin-convinced-that-Russia-Venezuela-should-continue-developing-strengthening-relations/|title=Putin sends condolences to Venezuelan people over Chavez's death|publisher=The Voice of Russia|date=6 March 2013|accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2013_03_06/Medvedev-sends-condolences-to-Venezuela-over-Chavezs-death/|title=Medvedev sends condolences to Venezuela over Chavez's death|publisher=The Voice of Russia|date=6 March 2013|accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> Russia would send a delegation consisting of [[Rosneft]] president [[Igor Sechin]], Trade and Industry minister [[Denis Manturov]], [[Rostec]] CEO [[Sergey Chemezov]], [[Federation Council]] speaker [[Valentina Matviyenko]] and foreign minister [[Sergei Lavrov]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.ruvr.ru/2013_03_06/Sechin-Manturov-Chemezov-to-represent-Russia-at-Chavezs-funeral/|title=Sechin, Manturov, Chemezov to represent Russia at Chavez's funeral|publisher=The Voice of Russia|date=6 March 2013|accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> Serbian president [[Tomislav Nikolić]] and prime minister [[Ivica Dačić]] sent condolences and lamented the loss of "a friend". Serbian cabinet also announced that he had been posthumously honoured with the Order of the Republic of Serbia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2013&mm=03&dd=06&nav_id=85018 |title=Info – Serbia honors Chavez with state decoration |publisher=B92 |accessdate=8 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022042309/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics-article.php?yyyy=2013&mm=03&dd=06&nav_id=85018 |archivedate=22 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> Belarus declared three days of mourning<ref>{{cite news|title=Isolated Belarus mourns death of "brother" Chavez|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/06/us-venezuela-chavez-belarus-idUSBRE9250YJ20130306|accessdate=6 March 2013|date=6 March 2013|agency=Reuters|location=MINSK|first=Andrei|last=Makhovsky}}</ref>
In the Vatican, a condolence letter was read during a [[College of Cardinals|meeting of Cardinals]] prior to the [[Papal conclave, 2013|Papal Conclave]].
====Oceania==== Australian Foreign Minister [[Bob Carr]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/breaking-news/carr-extends-condolences-to-venezuela/story-e6freono-1226591862360 |title=Carr extends condolences to Venezuela |publisher=couriermail.com.au |date=6 March 2013 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref> and New Zealand Prime Minister [[John Key]] expressed condolences "to the Chavez family and the people of Venezuela".<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/8393017/Chavezs-death-delays-Key-trade-talks|title=Chavez's death delays Key trade talks |author=ANDREA VANCE|location=BOGOTA|date=7 March 2013|publisher=Stuff.co.nz}}</ref> However, Key, who was on a diplomatic trip to Mexico, Colombia, Chile and Brazil, did not attend the funeral although meetings had been postponed due to Latin American leaders attending, and was criticized by ex-[[Green Party of Aotearoa New Zealand|Greens]] MP [[Keith Locke]], [[Toby Manhire]] and others.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/opinion/news/article.cfm?c_id=466&objectid=10869811 | title=Political round-up: John Key's snub of Venezuela | work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] | date=7 March 2013 | accessdate=1 December 2015 | author=Edwards, Bryce}}</ref>
==Funeral== [[File:Multitud chavez cortejo funebre 06032013.JPG|250px|thumb|right|Chávez's funeral procession]] Foreign minister [[Elías Jaua]] decreed seven days of mourning for Chávez.<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez dies|url=http://www.breakingnews.com/topic/venezuelan-president-hugo-chavez-dies|work=breaking news|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref> Chávez's body was taken to the Military Academy in Caracas on 6 March 2013, accompanied by large numbers of supporters who joined the procession at the military parade grounds (the Heroes Avenue) and was left lying in state for the public to visit for three days. The state funeral was held in Caracas on 8 March 2013.<ref name=dindon/><ref>{{cite news|first=Frank|last=Bajak|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/venezuelas-hugo-chavez-died-18659546|title=Hugo Chavez, Fiery Venezuelan Leader, Dies at 58|publisher=ABC News|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Chris|last=Kraul|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/world/worldnow/la-fg-wn-chavez-dies-20130305,0,7894283.story|title=Venezuelan strongman Hugo Chavez dead after struggle with cancer|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=5 March 2013|accessdate=5 March 2013}}</ref> Acting President [[Nicolás Maduro]] originally stated that Chávez's body would be embalmed and permanently displayed after the state funeral in a transparent sarcophagus at a military museum in the former site of the Military Academy in La Planicie Barracks at the [[23 de Enero]] district west of the city proper.<ref>{{cite web|title=Maduro: Chavez body to be permanently displayed|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/03/07/17226935-maduro-chavez-body-to-be-permanently-displayed?lite|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Hugo Chávez's body to be embalmed and displayed 'eternally'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/mar/07/hugo-chavez-funeral-disputed-burial|work=The Guardian|accessdate=8 March 2013|location=London|first1=Rory|last1=Carroll|first2=Virginia|last2=Lopez|date=7 March 2013}}</ref> However, due to difficulties in finding an expert and the uncertainties of plastination in which the weather plays a substantial part, Maduro announced that the body would not be embalmed in time.<ref>{{cite news|title=Venezuela says embalming of Chavez' body 'unlikely'|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-21780374|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=16 March 2013|date=13 March 2013}}</ref> President Maduro extended national mourning from 4 to 11 days to coincide with the transportation of the body to the military museum (now Museum of the Revolution) at La Planicie Barracks, which was renamed [[Montaña Barracks|Mountain Barracks]] as it was, not by accident, the place which the then Army LtCol Chavez captured and used as a command centre in the brief coup of 1992, and where he uttered his famous words "''Por ahora''" (For now) to the press.
His body was interred with full military honors on 15 March 2016, in a televised service, three years after his death.<ref name=Luto-Vzla-Extendido>{{cite news|title=Venezuela extiende duelo nacional por muerte de Comandante Chávez|url=http://www.telesurtv.net/articulos/2013/03/13/venezuela-extiende-hasta-el-15-de-marzo-duelo-nacional-por-muerte-de-comandante-chavez-4651.html|date=13 March 2013|accessdate=18 March 2013|work=teleSUR-TSJ/MM|language=Spanish}}</ref>
For the final arrangements a funeral service was arranged, with the casket leaving the Military Academy grounds in Fort Tiuna on 17 March 2013 under full military honours including references to Ltn. Cnl. Chavez's home battalion (the Apure Braves 414th Armored Battalion) with the marching song "Patria Querida" (Fatherland Beloved) played in slow time, a [[21-gun salute]], and a Military Aviation (formerly Venezuelan Air Force) flyover by [[Sukhoi Su-30]] fighters in a [[missing man formation]]. Government party militias in their light motorcycles followed the motorcade (itself surrounded by Army mounted guards) with a large following of (mostly poor) citizens, with final arrival honors paid upon arrival at the Mountain Barracks.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} Bolivian President Evo Morales, President Maduro (then interim) and Chavez's brother Adan and daughter Maria Gabiela each gave speeches before the flag folding and dedication ceremony. The national flag covering the casket was handed to Elena Frías de Chávez, the late President's mother, on behalf of the armed forces and the nation.

[[File:IDB logo.gif|20px]] [[Inter-American Development Bank]] || President || [[Luis Alberto Moreno]]<ref name = "Cristina"/> |} </center> [[File:Hugo Chavez funeral 2.jpg|700px|thumb|center|<center>Foreign dignitaries, Chávez's family and Venezuelan officials gathered around Chávez's casket.</center>]] Argentinian president [[Cristina Kirchner]] was amongst the first heads of state to arrive in Venezuela on Tuesday 5 March. She visited the chapel at the military hospital to pay her final respects on Thursday before returning home,<ref name = "Cristina">{{cite web |url=http://en.mercopress.com/2013/03/08/emotional-cristina-fernandez-back-in-argentina-misses-chavez-funeral-ceremony |title=Emotional Cristina Fernandez back in Argentina misses Chavez funeral ceremony |date=8 March 2013 |publisher= [[MercoPress]] |accessdate=11 March 2013}}</ref> citing health reasons.<ref name = "Rousseff"/> Brazilian president [[Dilma Rousseff]] attended a [[Wake (ceremony)|wake]] on Thursday at the military academy before returning to Brazil on Friday morning.<ref name = "Rousseff">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/03/09/us-venezuela-chavez-rousseff-idUSBRE9280G320130309 |title=Brazilian leftist Rousseff distances herself from Chavez |agency=Reuters |date= 9 March 2013 |accessdate=11 March 2013}}</ref> Former President [[Lula da Silva]] accompanied President Rousseff and departed before the funeral service.
Former Canadian prime minister [[Jean Chrétien]] and his wife [[Aline Chrétien|Aline]] attended the funeral,<ref>{{cite news|title=Chrétien among eclectic mix of dignitaries, leaders who attended Chavez funeral |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/jean-chrtien-among-eclectic-mix-of-dignitaries-leaders-who-attended-chavez-funeral/article9559388/ |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |date=8 March 2013 |location=Toronto |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130311214343/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/jean-chrtien-among-eclectic-mix-of-dignitaries-leaders-who-attended-chavez-funeral/article9559388/ |archivedate=11 March 2013 }}</ref> along with former Colombian senator [[Piedad Córdoba]], former Honduran president [[Manuel Zelaya]], and former Paraguayan president [[Fernando Lugo]].
Other attendees included Former US congressman [[William Delahunt]], President of Russian [[Rosneft]] oil company [[Igor Sechin]] and CEO of [[Rostec]] [[Sergei Chemezov]];<ref name="en.ria.ru"/> Nikolay Lukashenko, son of the Belarus president; [[Alexis Tsipras]], the leader of [[SYRIZA]] in Greece (later Prime Minister of Greece); from Spain were [[Cayo Lara]] and [[Willy Meyer Pleite]] ([[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.izquierda-unida.es/node/11892/ |title=Cayo Lara y Willy Meyer viajan a Caracas para asistir en representación de Izquierda Unida al funeral de Hugo Chávez | IZQUIERDA UNIDA |publisher=Izquierda-unida.es |accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> American civil rights activist [[Jesse Jackson]] and actor [[Sean Penn]] also attended.<ref>{{cite web |author=Brock Keeling |url=http://sfist.com/2013/03/08/sean_penn_attends_hugo_chavezs_fune.php |title=Sean Penn, Rev. Jesse Jackson Attend Hugo Chavez's Funeral |publisher=SFist |date=8 March 2013 |accessdate=15 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130312053858/http://sfist.com/2013/03/08/sean_penn_attends_hugo_chavezs_fune.php |archivedate=12 March 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/03/08/17234923-dramatic-exit-heads-of-state-gather-for-hugo-chavezs-funeral |title=Heads of State gather for Hugo Chavez funeral|publisher=NBC News |date=24 October 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref>
Honour guards were provided by the cadets of the component service academies of the Venezuelan Bolivarian Military University and by personnel of the [[Presidential Honor Guard Brigade]], among others.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}} The Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra provided musical accompaniment during the state funeral services.
==Tomb== [[File:Tumba Hugo Chávez Cuartel de la Montaña Caracas Venezuela.JPG|250px|thumbnail|right|Mausoleum of Hugo Chávez.]] Echoing strong national sentiment the Government elevated a proposal to the National Assembly (Parliament) for a statute amendment that would allow placing the late president's body near that of Simón Bolívar (the Liberator and father of the country) in the [[National Pantheon of Venezuela]], a secular building housing the remains and/or cenotaphs to independence war heroes and former presidents. The statute (still unamended) requires that a number of years pass before any such moves. Chávez's remains were placed instead at a mausoleum (built in 99 days) at the now Revolution Museum (formerly Army Museum) at the Mountain Barracks (former site of the Military Academy in La Planicie Barracks). The mausoleum to Hugo Chávez consists of a granite sarcophagus atop a flat architectural composition of four leaves entitled ''Flower of the Four Elements'' by modernist architect 'Fruto' (Jose Fructoso) Vivas (1928–) (national Architecture Price and designer of the Venezuelan Pavilion at Hanover in 2000) and has a permanent ceremonial 4-man honour guard provided by the Presidential Honor Guard Brigade, which is changed every hour. A 19th century cannon is fired every afternoon from the Fort marking the time of his death by a National Militia gun crew. Both ceremonies are open to the public.
==Foreign media commentary== The [[BBC]] quoted analysts as saying Chávez' death could alter the balance against the so-called "[[pink tide]]" in favour of centrist governments. It also suggested a possible economic impact due Venezuelan oil sales at below market prices to some neighbouring countries, especially in the Caribbean.<ref name="bbc"/> ''[[Americas Quarterly]]'' editor Christopher Sabatini suggested that the "Chávez myth" would outlive his achievements.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://globalpublicsquare.blogs.cnn.com/2013/03/05/chavez-myth-will-outlive-his-achievements/ |title=Chavez myth will outlive his achievements |publisher=CNN |accessdate=6 March 2013 |date=5 March 2013}}</ref> Prior to his death, Venezuela's [[International recognition of Abkhazia and South Ossetia|recognition of Abkhazia and South Ossetia]] were also highlighted as dependent on Chávez.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://taklama.com/2013/01/16/succession-of-chavez-also-affects-abkhazia-and-south-ossetia/ |title=Succession of Chavez also affects Abkhazia and South Ossetia |publisher=Taklama |date=16 January 2013 |accessdate=6 March 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category|Funeral of Hugo Chávez}} * [http://www.presidencia.gob.ve/ Official website of the Venezuelan Government]
{{Hugo Chávez}} {{Portal bar|2010s|Death|Politics|Socialism|Venezuela}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Death and state funeral of Hugo Chávez}} [[Category:2013 in Venezuela]] [[Category:Deaths by person|Chávez, Hugo]] [[Category:Hugo Chávez]] [[Category:State funerals|Chávez, Hugo]] [[Category:Funerals in Venezuela|Chávez, Hugo]] [[Category:Funerals by person|Chávez, Hugo]] [[Category:March 2013 events]]

The '''Dugu''' is an ancient extended funerary ceremony (in Belize it is also known as the 9 nights ceremony) practiced by the [[Garifuna people]]. The Garifuna is a small-to-medium-sized Central American ethnic group that has inhabited many [[Central American]] countries such as [[Belize]] and [[Honduras]] since the 17th century.<ref>Sletto 1991 {{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> Their roots come from both the [[Caribbean]] and [[Africa]]n coasts. The story goes that slaves being brought over to the Americas crashed into{{Clarify|date=March 2010|reason='were wrecked on'? or 'settled on'?}} [[Saint Vincent (island)|St. Vincent]]. The indigenous Caribbean Indians and Africans soon formed a community and ethnic group called the Garifuna. They were identified as the "Black Caribs" to differentiate them from the native Caribbean population.
The ''Dugu'' is a type of funeral ceremony that brings the community and families together. It is a festival that aims to bring deceased ancestors of the [[Garifuna people|Garifuna]] to the present<ref>Sletto 1991 {{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> and lasts between two days to as much as two weeks. The ceremony seeks to cure ill persons that have become sick because they have displeased the ''[[gubida]]'' (spirits).<ref>Jenkins 1983 {{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> Families and friends gather around drums and sing, calling the ''gubida'' to the ceremony. This ceremony is headed by the ''[[Buyai]]'' (shaman).<ref>Sletto 1991 {{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> The [[Buyai]] is responsible for organizing and ordering all parts of the ceremony including food, clothes worn, sacrifices, and its length.<ref>Jenkins 1983 {{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> Once the [[Buyai]] believes the spirits of the ancestors are present, the sick person is given food and rum. The rest of the food and alcohol is sacrificed and the person is predicted{{Clarify|date=March 2010|reason='predicted'? or 'considered'?}} to be cured.<ref>Sletto 1991 {{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref>
The ''Dugu'' ritual has recently become more common. In the 1850s and 1860s the ''Dugu'' was little practiced due to fear the government (appointed by the British) would ban the ritual altogether.<ref>Sletto 1991 {{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> Now, however, the ''Dugu ji'' is practiced in many countries throughout [[Central America]], but mainly in [[Belize]].<ref>Jenkins 1983 {{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref> There are many reasons for the increase, one of which is to help unify the [[Garifuna people|Garifuna]] people and also become politically visible as an ethnic group{{Clarify|date=March 2010|reason=these seem like outcomes rather than causes, but without access to the sources it's hard to be sure what is meant}}.<ref>Jenkins 1983 {{Page needed|date=September 2010}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==References== Palacio, I. Myrtle (2011 (June)). "Adügürahani: A Walk Through Garifuna Spiritualism". Glessima Research and Services, Belize.
Jenkins, Carol L. (1983 (Aug.)). "Ritual and Resource Flow: The Garifuna 'Dugu'". American Ethnologist. Vol 10.3 pp. 429–442. Retrieved 2009-09-20.
Sletto, Jacqueline Wiora. (1991(Jan-Feb)). "Ancestral Ties that Bind. (The Garifuna, Central American Ethnic Group)". Americas (English Edition). Vol 43.n1 pp. 20–28. Retrieved 2009-09-18.

[[Image:Dunk elephant.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Dunk with a keeper.]] '''Dunk''' (c. 1861 – March 30, 1917),<ref>"Dunk, Zoo Elephant, Hurt, Is Shot, And Children Mourn Death of Pet", ''Washington Post'', March 31, 1917.</ref> a tuskless, male [[Asian Elephant]] possibly from [[Ceylon]], was the first elephant to reside at the [[National Zoological Park (United States)|National Zoo in Washington, D.C.]] He was given to the National Zoo on April 30, 1891 by [[James E. Cooper]], owner and manager of the [[Adam Forepaugh]] [[Circus]].
When Dunk first arrived at the National Zoo, he had no shelter and was tied to a tree with his companion [[Gold Dust (elephant)|Gold Dust]] to prevent him from wandering. Once a day, both elephants were walked to [[Rock Creek (Potomac River)|Rock Creek]] to swim. A temporary structure, known as the Octagonal House, was eventually built for the elephants. Construction on a permanent, brick elephant house, designed by [[Hornblower & Marshall]], began in September 1902 and was completed in January 1903.
Dunk was ill throughout the winter of 1917. On March 30, 1917, after Dunk broke his shoulder in a fall, keeper [[William Blackburne]] [[euthanasia|euthanized]] him by shooting.
Despite a famous ill-temper, Dunk was popular with the children of Washington, D.C. To commemorate his memory, they raised money for a plaque, which remains in the elephant house at the National Zoo today.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://sirismm.si.edu/siahistory/imagedb/2003-19538.jpg Smithsonian online catalog image of Gold Dust (left) and Dunk (right) taking a walk together] *[http://sirismm.si.edu/siahistory/imagedb/mah-15530.jpg Smithsonian online catalog image of Dunk's elephant house] *[http://sirismm.si.edu/siahistory/imagedb/2002-10618.jpg Another Smithsonian online catalog image of Dunk's elephant house]

revision.text:
In '''''Estate Orpen v Estate Atkinson''''', an important case in the [[Law of succession in South Africa|South African law of succession]], the [[testator]]s, the Atkinsons, massed their [[estate (law)|estates]] in a [[Joint wills and mutual wills|joint will]]. They had one child, a daughter. According to the stipulations of the [[Will (law)|will]], the massed estate would, upon the death of Mr. Atkinson, should he die first, be handed over to the [[executor]]s of the estate, who would act as [[trustee]]s; a [[Trust law|trust]] was thus created.
From the moment of death of the testator, Mrs. Atkinson, also a testator, and the daughter would receive the [[income]] of the trust in equal parts as beneficiaries. Should one of them have died, the survivor would receive the whole of the trust income for the rest of her life. Should the daughter have died, the whole trust (the ''corpus'') would go to her children in [[per stirpes|equal shares]], subject to the [[usufruct]] of Mrs. Atkinson should she still be alive.
The will also stipulated that if the daughter should, upon death, have no children, twenty per cent of the [[trust capital]] (corpus) would go to such person as the daughter might designate in her will. She therefore obtained a [[power of appointment]] in her parents’ will with regard to twenty per cent of the corpus of the trust. The destination of the other eighty per cent was arranged for in the parents' will.
On 5 March 1963, while her father was still alive, the daughter (Mrs. Orpen) made a will in which, with reference to her power of appointment, she bequeathed the twenty per cent trust capital to her husband, Mr. Orpen. She thus exercised her power of appointment in favour of her spouse. Mrs. Orpen died on 23 March 1963 without children. Her father, Mr. Atkinson, the creator of the power of appointment, died on 9 November 1963. Mr. Orpen died on 23 December 1964.
The legal question was whether the exercise of Mrs. Orpen’s power of appointment in favour of Mr. Orpen, in terms of her father’s will, was valid, and whether her [[spouse]]’s deceased estate had obtained [[vested right]]s with regard to the twenty per cent trust capital that she bequeathed to him, regardless of the fact that she died before her father. Her father was therefore still alive when her will, in which she exercised her power of appointment, came into operation.
The Court held that Mr. Orpen’s estate had no right to twenty per cent of the trust capital. Mrs. Orpen obtained her "power" from her father; she could not exercise it unless she survived her father. Because he was still alive when she died, she could not exercise rights left to her in his will. She could only validly exercise her rights if she survived him.
== See also == * [[Law of succession in South Africa]]
== References == * ''Estate Orpen v Estate Atkinson'' 1966 (4) SA 589 (A).
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
